Based upon the nature of the planned activity, the city manager shall have the discretion to specify a wider area of notification as a condition of issuance of the permit. 
(c)  Notification should include all available information concerning the location and duration of the filming, preparation and wrap activities, the times of day required for each location, proposed parking restrictions and restrictions on public streets, proposed locations for all support facilities, as well as specifics regarding the use of lights, noise and any special effects or extraordinary equipment. The notification shall also include the film company's production office telephone number and the location manager's telephone/cell phone/pager numbers. 
(d)  After commencement of the filming activity, the film company shall provide written notification to the affected businesses and residents of any subsequent changes to the information provided in the original notification and of any additional variances or permits granted by the city to the filming company. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 9, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-180. - Special effects, explosives and similar devices. 
(a)  No film production which involves the use of explosives, pyrotechnics, fire or other special effects which involve flames or incendiary devices may be undertaken unless approval from the county fire marshal, county fire department and/or state fire marshal offices have been obtained. 
(b)  Any permits necessary for the use of explosives, pyrotechnics, fire or other special effects which involve flames or incendiary devices are the responsibility of the film production company. A copy of any permits required not issued by the city must be submitted. 
(c)  Use of public water by way of hydrant hookup shall require coordination with the city. Payment for any such water consumed shall be the responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 10, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-181. - Fees. 
Fees for various permits, applications or other requirements of this article will be contained in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 11, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-182. - Denial; term; revocation; suspension. 
(a)  Denial. Where the film permit is denied, the applicant shall be notified in writing by mail within five working days of denial and the reasons therefor. 
(b)  Term. Permits issued pursuant to this article shall be effective for the stated purpose and dates specified in the permit. 
(c)  Revocation or suspension. A film production permit may be revoked or suspended for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Material false statement contained in the application; 
(2)  Failure to comply with federal, state or municipal laws and regulations; 
(3)  Failure to comply with any conditions imposed by the city on the issuance of the film production permit; 
(4)  Failure to operate the film production in accordance with such ordinances, laws, orders, rules and regulations as may be applicable; 
(5)  Conducting the film production business or activity in a fraudulent or disorderly manner or in a manner which endangers the public health, safety, or welfare, or in any manner which disrupts the public peace. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 12, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-183. - Residential locations. 
Filming in residential neighborhoods shall be limited to the hours between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., unless specified otherwise in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 13, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-184. - Clean-up. 
The permittee shall conduct operations in an orderly fashion with continuous attention to the storage of equipment not in use and the clean-up of trash and debris. The area used shall be cleaned of trash and debris upon completion of shooting at the scene and restored to the original condition before leaving the site. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 14, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-185. - Filming on private property. 
A permittee must obtain permission, consent and/or secure a lease for any use of property not owned or controlled by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 15, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-186. - Traffic control. 
In the event the filming activity will require the closure of traffic lanes or will impair the flow of traffic, the applicant will be required to submit a traffic control plan for review to the city. No permit will be issued until the traffic control plan has been approved. 
(1)  In the event any filming impairs traffic flow, permittees may be required to use local law enforcement personnel for traffic control purposes and comply with other traffic control requirements as deemed necessary by the city. 
(2)  Permittees shall furnish and install advance warning signs and any other traffic control devices in conformance with the National Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). The city may, at its discretion, require additional signage other than that required by the MUTCD. 
(3)  For any lane closure or intermittent traffic control, the period of time that traffic may be restricted will be determined by the city based on traffic volumes for the location and time of day. 
(4)  Traffic shall not be detoured across a double line without prior authorization of the city. 
(5)  Unless authorized by the city, any camera cars must be driven in the direction of traffic and must observe all traffic laws. 
(6)  Any emergency work by city crews and/or private contractors, under permit or contract to the city, shall have priority over filming activities. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 16, 2-9-2015) 
Sec. 16-187. - Operations center; parking. 
(a)  In the event an operations center, also known as a base camp, is utilized, a site plan must be submitted. The site plan shall include the location address, layout of any trailers, storage facilities, and parking, etc. 
(b)  If a film production company desires to park equipment, trucks and/or cars in restricted parking zones, roadways or rights-of-way, temporary "No Parking" signs must be posted, subject to the prior approval of the city. In addition, authorization is required to lay and safely mat cable across sidewalks or roadways from a generator to a service point. 
(Ord. No. 2015-003, § 17, 2-9-2015) 
Chapter 18 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
(RESERVED) 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Chapter 20 - NUISANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. title 41. 

Sec. 20-1. - Abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any vehicle within the city, whether on a public street or private property, and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the city for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
(b)  It shall be further unlawful for any person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, to allow any partially dismantled, non-operating, wrecked, junked or discarded vehicle to remain on such property longer than seven days; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property including any roadway, street or right-of-way within the city for a longer time than seven days; except that this chapter shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; a vehicle in storage as defined herein; or a depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(c)  Upon violation hereof, the city shall be authorized, after notice as provided herein, to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this chapter or lost, stolen or unclaimed. Any fine, removal fee, and impoundment fee may be assessed against the owner of the vehicle or the owner of the property by the municipal court for the city. 
(d)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Notice means written notice by first class mail to the registered owner of the vehicle, if known, or to the property owner, tenant, occupant or lessee where said vehicle is located. 
Property means any real property within the city which is not a street or highway. 
Storage means concealment in an enclosed, permanent structure, concealment by a privacy fence of at least eight feet in height, or concealment by a planting of natural shrubs or bushes of at least eight feet in height, which structure, fence or planting conceals the vehicle from view from any residence other than the residence located on the property in which the vehicle is being stored and from public view from any street or highway. 
Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transport persons or property or pull machinery, and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons. 
(Ord. of 8-9-1999) 
State Law reference— Abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-8 et seq. 
Chapter 22 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Use of railroad right-of-way. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to use or cause to be used the railroad right-of-way between the northern city limits and the Highway 41 overpass for the purpose of overnight camping or for the purpose of storage of equipment. 
(Ord. of 6-9-1986) 
Sec. 22-2. - Disorderly conduct. 
The following acts are declared to be disorderly conduct and unlawful: 
(1)  Public use of obscene, abusive or profane language; 
(2)  Making of any threat of violence to or against any other person; 
(3)  Being noisy and disorderly in or upon any street or other public place in the city; 
(4)  The reckless and dangerous use of firearms or dangerous weapons; 
(5)  Any noisy or riotous conduct to the disturbance of the public peace and tranquility; 
(6)  Engaging in, promoting, encouraging, aiding or abetting any fight, riot or noisy and disorderly proceeding on any street or public place; 
(7)  Maintaining, being in possession of or control of any private building or dwelling where persons residing in the vicinity are disturbed by disorderly proceedings and/or illegal activities, riotous conduct, dangerous use of firearms, fighting, obscene, abusive or profane language; or 
(8)  Maintaining, being in possession of or control of any private building or dwelling where disorderly proceedings and/or illegal activities, riotous conduct, dangerous use of firearms, fighting, or use of obscene, abusive or profane language are taking place. 
(Ord. of 11-24-1986(1); Ord. of 11-24-1986(2)) 
Sec. 22-3. - Possession of open container of alcohol in street or public place. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any alcoholic or malt beverages in any open container upon any street or public place within the city. The provisions of this section do not apply in motor vehicles. 
(Ord. of 11-24-1986(4)) 
Secs. 22-4—22-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 22-25. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Emerson Special Events Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 1, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-26. - Purpose. 
The city council recognizes the impact that special events have on the availability of city services, and the city council further recognizes the dangerous nature of fireworks to the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city, and therefore adopts this procedure to license and regulate activities of this nature. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 2, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-27. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fireworks means any combustible or explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, or detonation, including blank cartridges, balloons requiring fire underneath to propel them, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs, sparklers and other combustibles and explosives of like construction, as well as articles containing any explosive or flammable compound and tablets and other devices containing an explosive substance. 
Nonprofit organizations means 501(c)(3)-approved organizations including, but not limited to, religious, educational, charitable, scientific, literary, testing for public safety, fostering national or international amateur sports competition, or prevention of cruelty to children or animal organizations. 
Parades, marches and processions means a group or number of people or vehicles, or the combination thereof, consisting of five or more vehicles or ten or more persons, or a combination of three or more vehicles and five or more persons, proceeding or moving in a body or in concert along the streets or sidewalks of the city. 
Road race means any race on public rights-of-way that requires the closing of such rights-of-way or otherwise impedes the flow of normal traffic. 
Special event , as used in this article, means: 
(1)  Any activity which occurs upon private or public property that will affect the ordinary use of parks, public streets, rights-of-way, sidewalks, or which otherwise impacts the delivery of public safety services. 
(2)  Any activity which causes an increase of more than 100 percent in average daily trips on any public street within the city. 
(3)  The term "special event" includes, but is not limited to, fairs, tours, grand opening celebrations, races, parades, arts festivals, concerts, holiday celebrations, bicycle runs and block parties. Private social gatherings which will make no use of city streets other than for lawful parking are not included. Garage sales, lawn sales, rummage sales, flea market sales or any similar casual sales of tangible personal property are not included. 
Special event permit means the permit required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 3, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-28. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on a special event, parade, march, procession, or road race or discharge fireworks on private or public property within the limits of the city without first applying for or receiving a special event permit from the city. This is in addition to any permit that may be required by the International Fire Code or any other applicable code or law. Special event permits are a privilege, and as such, may be denied, revoked or suspended for any cause as deemed appropriate by the city. 
(b)  Any special event which is designed or intended to attract the participation or attendance of 50 or more individuals at any given point in time, or at which any fireworks shall be used, exploded or displayed, shall require a permit. 
(c)  Nonprofit organizations are not exempt from obtaining a special event permit but may be exempt from paying applicable fees. 
(d)  No person shall advertise, engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any special event, unless a special event permit shall first have been obtained from the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 4, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-29. - Exemptions. 
This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Lawful picketing. Lawful picketing shall be conducted off the street or roadway and not in a manner as to obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Any lawful picketing which crosses, traverses, or is otherwise conducted in or upon any street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk shall not be exempted from the permit requirement. 
(3)  Activities of, or sponsored by, a governmental agency that do not require the closing of any street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk. 
(4)  Any bona fide athletic event or contest which is scheduled and sponsored by any bona fide elementary school, secondary school, or high school situated within the city, so long as during such special event no fireworks shall be used, exploded, or displayed and that does not require the closing of any street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk. 
(5)  Any bona fide athletic event held by a business licensed in the city to hold athletic events, so long as during such event no fireworks shall be used, exploded, or displayed and that does not require the closing of any street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 5, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-30. - Administration. 
The city manager or his designee shall be responsible for administering the provisions of this article. The city manager is authorized to act as the agent for the city in the receipt, processing and approval of applications for special event permits. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 6, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-31. - Application. 
(a)  Any person seeking the issuance of a special events permit shall complete the written application form provided by the city and shall provide all information therein and file that written application with the city. An application for a permit (that does not involve closing of a street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk) shall be filed not more than 180 days and not less than 60 days before the date and time which the proposed special event is to take place. However, for just cause, the city manager may waive the minimum 60-day filing period and accept an application filed within a shorter period if, after consideration of the date, time, place and nature of the special event, the number of participants and the necessity for city services which will be required in connection with the special event, the city manager reasonably deems it appropriate to waive the filing period. If the proposed special event is associated with freedom of speech (and requires no closure of a street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk) the minimum filing period is seven days. Applications shall include: 
(1)  The name, place of residence, mailing address, e-mail address and telephone number of the person applying for the permit. 
(2)  If the event is to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization must be provided. 
(3)  The name, place of residence, mailing address, e-mail address and telephone number of the individual person responsible for conducting the event. 
(4)  The dates and times scheduled for the event. 
(5)  The exact location/street address of the event. (Attach a copy of a rental/lease agreement if the property is owned by someone other than the applicant.) 
(6)  A detailed plan/layout of the event (to include placement of tents, chairs, tables, stages, port-a-johns, dumpsters, etc.). If the event involves the closing of a street, roadway, right-of-way or sidewalk, a detailed layout of the route to be taken (including starting and ending points), roads involved, dates, times and length of times roads will need to be closed, whether or not a full road closure is needed or if a rolling closure can be done, and the purpose of closing the road, must be submitted with application. 
(7)  The nature and types of activities that will occur, as well as stating how trash disposal and access to toilets will be handled. If the event is scheduled to last two hours or longer, the entity filing the special event permit application is required to provide a sufficient number of port-a-johns for event attendees, to be determined by the city. Said entity is also responsible for the disposal of trash generated by its event. The determination of whether port-a-johns and trash dumpsters are required and the number of port-a-johns and size of dumpsters rests solely with the city, with the reservation and costs of such provisions being the sole responsibility of the special event permit applicant. 
(8)  The approximate number of spectators and participants present or participating in the event. 
(9)  The purpose of the event. 
(10)  If the event is a parade, the following additional information shall be required: 
a.  The exact location of any marshaling or staging areas for the parade. 
b.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to arrive at the staging areas, and the times at which all such units will be dispersed therefrom. 
c.  The exact route to be traveled, including the starting point and termination point. 
d.  The approximate number of persons, animals and vehicles which will participate in the parade, including a description of the types of animals and vehicles to be used in the parade. 
e.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the street, roadway, or sidewalks to be used. 
f.  A designation of any public facilities or equipment proposed to be utilized. 
(11)  Attachment of all authorizations required by any other governmental agency possessing jurisdiction over the event, including, but not limited to: 
a.  Food service permit. 
b.  Sign permit. 
c.  Alcohol license. 
d.  Fireworks license (state) and permit (county). 
e.  Any other permit or license or authorization as may be required. 
(12)  The application shall be signed by the applicant under oath. 
(b)  The application for a special event permit shall constitute an agreement by the applicant to pay for city personnel expenses and extraordinary services provided by the city, including all repairs, renovations and landscaping and turf restoration or replacement which is necessitated by virtue of the event, unless another agreement to fix all damages to public property caused by the event is agreed upon by the applicant and the city. 
(c)  The application for a special event permit shall constitute a covenant between the applicant and the city, specifying that the applicant will halt or interrupt event proceedings upon instruction from an officer of the city police department or county fire department, upon violation of any state or local police or fire codes. The city covenants not to instruct that the event be halted or interrupted unless, in its discretion, it perceives that the event shall cause or coincide with interference with traffic movement, disturbance of the peace, destruction of property, violation of the law or a threat to the public peace, health, safety, or welfare. 
(d)  The applicant for a special event permit shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from all damages, suits, actions or liabilities, including all attorney's fees, resulting from acts of the special event company or its agents during the event activity. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 7, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-32. - Approval criteria. 
The city manager or his designee shall issue a permit as provided herein upon receipt that the following standards for issuance of the permit have been substantially satisfied or found not applicable to the requested permit: 
(1)  The conduct of the event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other pedestrians or vehicular traffic in or contiguous to the route or location of the event. 
(2)  The conduct of the event will not require the diversion of so great a number of public safety personnel or equipment of the city to properly secure the event area and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent the current level of public safety services from being furnished to other parts of the city. 
(3)  The event shall not take place until inspections by concerned departments have been conducted and a determination has been made that all codes and ordinances have been met and satisfied. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and/or vehicles at the event will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection or ambulance service to areas contiguous to the event area and other areas of the city. 
(5)  The conduct of the assembly is not reasonably likely to cause injury or intended to cause injury to persons or property or to provide disorderly conduct as defined by state statutes, provided that under no circumstances may the city deny a permit solely on the basis of the proposed content of speech or ideas of the group involved. 
(6)  Adequate sanitation and other required health facilities are or will be made available in or adjacent to the event area and the applicant has agreed to clean the right-of-way or public property of rubbish and debris, returning it to its pre-event condition, within 24 hours of the conclusion of the event, with the understanding that failure to do so will result in the city conducting the clean-up and charging the applicant with any and all costs associated with the clean-up. 
(7)  The conduct of the assembly will not result in noise at a level inappropriate for the areas surrounding the event or as may be restricted by ordinance or permit. 
(8)  There are sufficient parking places near the event to accommodate the approximate number of automobiles reasonably expected to be driven to the assembly. 
(9)  The applicant has secured parks and recreation, public works, police, fire and emergency medical services/protection, if any, required under this section, and has prepaid the expenses therefor. 
(10)  If the event is a parade, such parade is not to be held for the primary purpose of advertising any product, goods or event which is primarily for private profit; provided, however, that the prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring exhibits or structures used to conduct the event. 
(11)  If the event is a parade, and if the parade will traverse a state or federal highway, the persons or organization must also have a permit from the state department of transportation. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 8, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-33. - Insurance. 
(a)  Liability insurance. Proof of general liability insurance in the amount of at least $1,000,000.00 per incident or occurrence will be required before issuance of a permit, naming the city as an additional insured for protection against claims of personal injuries, wrongful death and property damage. The officers and employees of the city shall also be named as additional insured. The certificate shall not be subject to cancellation or modification until after 30 days' written notice to the city. A copy of the certificate shall remain on file at the city. 
(b)  Workers' compensation. Proof of workers' compensation insurance coverage for each and every employee in any way involved with the event will be required, under state and federal law. 
(c)  Fireworks. Proof of general liability insurance in the amount of at least $5,000,000.00 per incident or occurrence will be required before issuance of a permit, naming the city as an additional insured for protection against claims of personal injuries, wrongful death and property damage. The officers and employees of the city shall also be named as additional insured. The certificate shall not be subject to cancellation or modification until after 30 days' written notice to the city. A copy of the certificate shall remain on file at the city. 
(d)  Hold harmless agreement. A hold harmless agreement shall be executed by the applicant as provided by the city, pursuant to issuance of a permit. 
(e)  Security deposit. To ensure clean-up and restoration of the site, the city may require a security deposit in an amount to be determined by the city. The security deposit will be refunded if, after completion of the event, an inspection by the city of the site shows that no damage, debris or other significant occurrences related to the event have occurred. In the event the city inspection provides evidence of any of the aforementioned, the city shall be authorized to not refund the security deposit either in part or whole. This remedy in no manner restricts the ability of the city to make claim against the applicant's insurance company. 
(f)  Additional insurance. The city manager is authorized to require higher insurance amounts and any other insurances he deems appropriate due to the nature of the proposed special event. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 9, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-34. - Notification of affected residents and businesses. 
(a)  Following the submission of a special event permit application, but no less than 14 business days prior to commencement of the event, the event company shall notify, in writing, all businesses and residents affected by the proposed activity. The event company shall provide a signed copy of such notification to the city manager. Where the planned activity may have a significant and/or prolonged impact on the normal activities of the area (for example, activities impacting parking or traffic), the city manager shall have the discretion to require earlier notification. 
(b)  The area to be covered by the notification prescribed in subsection (a) of this section shall be a minimum of a 500-foot radius of the planned activity. Based upon the nature of the planned activity, the city manager shall have the discretion to specify a wider area of notification as a condition of issuance of the permit. 
(c)  Notification should include all available information concerning the location and duration of the special event, preparation and wrap activities, the times of day required for each location, proposed parking restrictions and restrictions on public streets, proposed locations for all support facilities, as well as specifics regarding the use of lights, noise and any fireworks. The notification shall also include the event company's office telephone number and the location manager's telephone, cell phone, and pager numbers. 
(d)  After commencement of the special event activity, the event company shall provide written notification to the affected businesses and residents of any subsequent changes to the information provided in the original notification, and of any additional variances or permits granted by the city to the event company. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 10, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-35. - Fees. 
Fees for various permits, applications or other requirements of this article will be contained in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 11, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-36. - Fee exemptions. 
(a)  All nonprofit or religious organizations shall be exempt from the payment of fees if the special event does not involve fireworks, a parade, the use of city facilities or the use of city personnel. A copy of the 501(c)(3) form must be provided. 
(b)  Activities of, or sponsored by, a governmental agency shall be exempt from the payment of fees if the special event does not involve fireworks, a parade, the use of city facilities or the use of city personnel. 
(c)  Any bona fide athletic event or contest which is scheduled and sponsored by any bona fide elementary school, secondary school, high school or college situated within the city shall be exempt from the payment of fees if the special event does not involve fireworks, a parade, the use of city facilities or the use of city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 12, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-37. - Standards for denial of permit. 
Reasons for denial of a special event permit, as determined by the city include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  The event will disrupt traffic within the city beyond practical resolution. 
(2)  The event will interfere with access to fire stations and/or fire hydrants. 
(3)  The location of the special event will cause undue hardship to adjacent businesses or residents. 
(4)  The event will require the diversion of so many public employees that allowing the event would unreasonably deny service to the remainder of the city. 
(5)  The application contains incomplete or false information. 
(6)  The applicant fails to comply with all terms of this article, including failure to remit all fees and deposits, or failure to provide proof of insurance/certificate of insurance, proof of authorization from applicable outside entities such as licenses or permits required by federal, state or county officials for alcohol licenses, food service, fireworks, bonds, and a hold harmless agreement to the city. 
(7)  Previous violations or uncooperativeness in prior permitted applications. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 13, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-38. - Denial; term; revocation; suspension. 
(a)  Denial. Where the special event permit is denied, the applicant shall be notified in writing by mail within five working days of denial and the reasons therefor. 
(b)  Term. Permits issued pursuant to this article shall be effective for the stated purpose and dates specified in the permit. 
(c)  Revocation or suspension. A special event permit may be revoked or suspended for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Material false statement contained in the application; 
(2)  Failure to comply with federal, state or municipal laws and regulations; 
(3)  Failure to comply with any conditions imposed by the city on the issuance of the special event permit; 
(4)  Failure to operate the event in accordance with such ordinances, laws, orders, rules and regulations as may be applicable; or 
(5)  Conducting the special event or activity in a fraudulent or disorderly manner or in a manner which endangers the public health, safety, welfare or which in any manner disrupts the public peace. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 14, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-39. - Clean-up. 
The permittee shall conduct operations in an orderly fashion with continuous attention to the storage of equipment not in use and the clean-up of trash and debris. The area used shall be cleaned of trash and debris upon completion of the event and restored to the original condition before leaving the site. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 15, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-40. - Traffic control. 
In the event the activity will require the closure of traffic lanes or will impair the flow of traffic, the applicant will be required to submit a traffic control plan for review to the city. No permit will be issued until the traffic control plan has been approved. 
(1)  In the event any event impairs traffic flow, permittees may be required to use local law enforcement personnel for traffic control purposes and comply with other traffic control requirements as deemed necessary by the city. 
(2)  Permittees shall furnish and install advance warning signs and any other traffic control devices in conformance with the National Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). The city may, at its discretion, require additional signage other than that required by the MUTCD. 
(3)  For any lane closure or intermittent traffic control, the period of time that traffic may be restricted will be determined by the city based on traffic volumes for locations and time of day. 
(4)  Traffic shall not be detoured across a double line without prior authorization of the city. 
(5)  Unless authorized by the city, any camera cars must be driven in the direction of traffic and must observe all traffic laws. 
(6)  Any emergency work by city crews and/or private contractors, under permit or contract to the city, shall have priority over filming activities. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 16, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-41. - Fireworks displays. 
No person, firm, partnership, or corporation shall expose, use or explode any fireworks unless a license shall first have been obtained from the state department of treasury, bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms division, and a permit has been obtained from the county. A copy of the following documents must be submitted with the special event permit application: 
(1)  A state license as issued by the state department of treasury, bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms division. 
(2)  An approval letter from the county fire marshal. 
(3)  A certificate of liability insurance. 
(4)  The firework company's contact name, address and telephone number. 
(5)  A detailed listing of the type and quantity of fireworks to be used. 
(6)  A detailed written statement outlining all appropriate safety procedures which will be used at the fireworks display in order to protect the safety of the public and all surrounding property, and number of city personnel necessary for the event. 
(7)  A detailed written statement describing what facilities and containers will be used to store fireworks. 
(8)  If applicable, the applicant's federal license number for transporting fireworks across state lines. 
(9)  A detailed list of the names, addresses, occupations, and backgrounds of all individuals who will be responsible for the actual display, use, or explosion of any fireworks. The background statement should include a complete history of the experience of the individuals involved with respect to their use of fireworks, including a detailed list and explanation of each and every accident resulting from the use of fireworks which the individuals have been responsible for or involved in. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 17, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-42. - Parades, marches and processions. 
Parades, marches and processions shall be considered special events as defined in this article and shall require issuance of a permit subject to the fees and conditions contained in this article and as specified in the subsections below. 
(1)  Prohibited without permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to be a part of or to engage in any parade, march, or procession or to march, parade or proceed along any street or sidewalk in the city as a part of or a party to such parade, march, or procession without having first obtained a written permit from the city manager or his designee for the holding of such parade, march or procession. 
(2)  Police vehicle to precede parades, marches and processions. All parades, marches and processions through the streets of the city shall be preceded by a police vehicle and conducted in such manner as to impede and interfere with the flow of traffic to the least possible extent. 
(3)  If the special event is a parade and if the parade will traverse a state or federal highway the persons or organization must also have a permit from the state department of transportation. 
This section does not apply to funeral processions, which are exempt from the special events ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 18, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-43. - Police; security. 
After obtaining the above information, the city shall determine whether and to what extent additional police protection will be required for the event for purposes of traffic, crowd control and security. If additional police protection for the event is deemed necessary by the city, it shall so inform the applicant for the permit. The applicant then shall have the obligation to secure police protection acceptable to the city at the sole expense of the applicant and shall pay the expenses of such protection as required. The city shall consider what additional manpower, equipment, and supplies are needed, as well as any other items or expenses which will be necessary. Private security may be used by the applicant with approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 19, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-44. - Fire protection; medical services. 
The county fire department, county fire marshal and county EMS shall make all determinations as to the need for on-site fire watch or emergency medical personnel. The applicant shall be required to follow the recommendations provided. All costs associated with the requirements for fire and medical personnel shall be at the expense of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 20, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-45. - Additional city services; personnel. 
After obtaining the above information, the city shall determine whether and to what extent additional city staff will be required for the event for purposes of traffic control, park and/or street cleaning and maintenance, etc. In making this determination, the city shall so inform the applicant for the permit. The applicant then shall have the obligation to secure event staff acceptable to the city at the sole expense of the applicant and shall pay the expenses of such maintenance as required. The city shall consider what additional manpower, equipment, and supplies are needed, as well as any other items or expenses which will be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 21, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-46. - Duties of permittee. 
A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. The event chairperson shall maintain custody of the permit, and upon demand, shall produce it to the city authorities. Under no circumstances may a permit be transferred from the applicant to any other person or organization. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 22, 3-9-2015) 
Sec. 22-47. - Interpretation. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed so as to exempt the applicant or any other person from the requirements of the Georgia code or any other applicable state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2015-004, § 23, 3-9-2015) 
Chapter 23 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Statement of intent. 
It is the purpose of this chapter and the rules and regulations set forth to establish a fair and uniform system of personnel administration for all employees of the city under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-2. - Objectives. 
These policies provide for the establishment of a classification and compensation plan, the recruitment, selection and appointment of qualified applicants, benefits for employees, holidays and leave of absences, employee responsibilities, ethics and conduct, probationary periods, performance evaluations, disciplinary and non-disciplinary action, grievances, separations and records and the establishment or orderly procedures for administering the personnel system in accordance with the following merit principles: 
(1)  Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge and skill, including open competition of qualified applicants for initial appointment; 
(2)  Establishing classification categories and pay rates consistent with the principles of providing comparable pay for comparable work; 
(3)  Training employees, as needed, to assure high quality performance; 
(4)  Retaining employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance, and separating employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected; 
(5)  Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex, religious creed, age or handicapped status, 
(6)  Establishing a procedure for the presentation and adjustment of employee or applicant grievances based on alleged inequitable treatment or alleged discrimination; 
(7)  Assuring employee's protection against partisan political coercion and prohibiting the use of official authority for interfering with or affecting the results of an election or the nomination for an office. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-3. - Application of policy. 
The personnel policy, except where specifically noted or exempted by law, shall apply to all regular, full and part time employees including probationary and temporary employees. The mayor and members of the city council and advisory boards and commissions shall not be subject to these personnel policies. As well, as a matter of course, independent contractors are not subject to the personnel policies. Independent contractors shall include, but not limited to, municipal court judges, municipal court solicitors, and municipal attorneys. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-4. - Formulating department rules and regulations. 
Each department head for the city shall be responsible for preparing a schedule of rules and regulations applicable to his respective department designed to insure the efficient operation of the department. Department rules shall be a complement to this chapter. A copy of the rules and regulations shall be, at all times, posted in a conspicuous place within the department for use by its personnel, as well as filed with the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-5. - Equal employment opportunity. 
The city is an equal employment opportunity employer and does not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of race, sex, age, color, religion, national origin, disabilities, marital status, pregnancy status, veteran's status or any other basis prohibited by federal, state or local law. We value and encourage diversity in our workforce. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-6. - Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). 
Individuals with disabilities who need reasonable accommodations, in order to apply or maintain employment, should contact Emerson City Hall at 770-382-9819. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-7. - Equal employment opportunity guaranteed. 
Any applicant, employee or other affected person who alleges discrimination or inequitable treatment in any personnel transaction shall have the right to discuss the matter fully with the appropriate department head. If the claim is not satisfactorily resolved, the aggrieved party may exercise the right of appeal to the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-8. - At will employment. 
It is the policy of the city that all employees do not have a written employment contract for a specific fixed term of employment. Any employment relationship with the city is "at will" in nature, which means that the employee may resign at any time and the employer may discharge the employee at any time with or without cause. Nothing in this chapter creates an employment contract or term between the city and its employees. No person has the authority to grant any employee any contractual rights of employment. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-9. - Responsibilities of city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint and discharge all employees subject to the conditions of these policies and shall be responsible for the administration of the personnel policies and rules contained within which shall apply to all appointed employees except those specifically exempted. The city manager may assign a designated representative to assist with the administration of this chapter. He shall continually monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of the compensation plan and shall recommend appropriate changes and revisions at any time necessary. At the time of budget preparation each year, he shall evaluate the entire pay structure, grade assignments, personnel salaries, pay scale and pay policies, and shall recommend appropriate changes and revisions to the mayor and city council as necessary. 
(b)  The city manager or his designated representative shall: 
(1)  Maintain a position classification plan; 
(2)  Develop and submit a pay plan for annual budget consideration; 
(3)  Publicize job vacancies to assure obtaining the most qualified applicants; 
(4)  Take job application and make information available to the proper supervisor; 
(5)  Be notified of all selections for hiring; 
(6)  Maintain appropriate central personnel records; and 
(7)  Recommend amendments and changes to the personnel policies. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-10. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
207(k) employee means an employee engaged in fire protection or law enforcement activities with 28-consecutive-day work periods. 
Accrual means the process of earning a benefit such as vacation or sick leave. 
Adverse action means an action taken by the city manager, or his designee, that results in a suspension without pay, salary reduction, demotion or dismissal. 
Anniversary date means the date the employee began his employment in the most recent position. 
Date of hire means the effective date of the individual's employment with the city. 
Discharge means termination of an employee by the city. 
Doctor means a doctor of medicine, osteopathy, dentist or dental surgeon currently holding an active state license. Also referred to as physician and/or medical professional. 
Exempt means employees exempted from the minimum wage and overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). 
Grievance means a condition thought to be unjust and grounds for a formal complaint. 
His. Use of this pronoun shall apply equally to both males and females. 
Immediate family includes spouse, child, parent, brother, sister, grandparents, parent-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law or grandchildren. The definition also includes any other person living in the employee's household who is recognized by state law as the employee's dependent. 
In-law means a relative by marriage such as mother-in-law, father-in-law, daughter-in-law and son-in-law. 
Layoff means termination of an employee by the city for lack of work, lack of funds, reorganization or other changes that have taken place. 
May. The term "may" is conditional and implies there is discretion concerning whether a condition exists or an action will take place. 
Nonexempt means employees covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
Outside employment means employment in a work outside of the duties as a city employee. This shall include self-employment and other business activity as well as working for a second employer. 
Overtime means all work performed in excess of the hours permitted under the Fair Labor Standards Act work period. 
Personnel records includes personnel and medical files. An employee's medical file shall be kept separate from his personnel file. 
Probation means a period during which a new employee or an employee who has been transferred, promoted or demoted is being tested on job capability and performance. 
Probationary employee. A person appointed to an allocated position who has not yet successfully completed the designated probationary period. A probationary employee may be rejected, dismissed, demoted or suspended without the right to appeal. An employee who successfully completes the probationary period will be considered a regular employee of the city. 
Regular employee means an employee who has successfully completed the probationary period and is assigned to a position which is regular full-time or regular part-time. 
Regular full-time employee means an employee who has successfully completed the probationary period, is assigned to a position which is expected to continue for an indefinite duration, and works a shift schedule which will total no less than 2,080 hours per year. 
Regular part-time employee means an employee who has successfully completed the probationary period, is assigned to a position which is expected to continue for an indefinite duration, and works a shift schedule of less than 40 hours per week. 
Shall/will. These terms are unconditional and imply that a condition exists or an action will take place. 
Temporary employee means an employee who is assigned to a position which is not expected to continue for an indefinite duration, generally short-term or seasonal. Temporary employees are paid on an hourly basis only for hours actually worked. They are not eligible for benefits except those mandated by state and federal government. The temporary employee or the city can at any time or for any reason terminate the employment relationship. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 1, § 10)) 
Secs. 23-11—23-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

Sec. 23-37. - Classified service defined. 
The classified service shall consist of all current classes of permanent positions with the city listed in the official classification plan approved by the city council except those positions exempted. The classification plan may consist of future classes of positions. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 2, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-38. - Classification procedures. 
(a)  The city manager is responsible for the administration and maintenance of the classification plan. He shall see that a job description be prepared and currently maintained for each position included in the personnel system. Each position shall be evaluated in relation to all other positions systematically grouped into categories of like duties and responsibilities, assigned a common title and organized into a classification plan. He shall also prepare and maintain current class specification outlining the distinguishing characteristics of work and desirable or required training and experience for each category of positions in the classified service. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each department head to submit to the city manager new position descriptions for all affected positions each time a department or division is permanently or substantially reorganized, when major changes in duties and responsibilities occur for any job, when a new position is requested, or at other times when the classification level of a position may be affected. 
(c)  New positions shall be established only with the approval of the city council, after which the city manager shall either: 
(1)  Allocate the new position to the appropriate class within the existing classification plan; or 
(2)  Recommend that the city council amend the position classification plan to establish a new class to which the new position may be allocated. 
(d)  When the city manager finds that a substantial change has occurred in the nature or level of duties and responsibilities of an existing position, he shall: 
(1)  Reallocate the position to the appropriate class within the existing classification plan; or 
(2)  Recommend that the city council amend the position classification plan to establish a new class to which the position may be allocated. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 2, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-39. - Official copy of the position classification plan. 
The city clerk shall be responsible for maintaining an official copy of the position classification plan, which shall include a current list of class titles and class specifications. A copy of the official plan shall be available for inspection by the public under reasonable conditions during business hours. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 2, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-40. - Classification appeals. 
Any employee who believes that his position is improperly classified may request, through the appropriate department head, that the city manager review the proper classification of the position. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 2, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-41. - Amendment to the plan. 
Classes of positions shall be added to and deleted from the position classification plan upon the recommendation of the city manager and with approval of the city council. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 2, § 5)) 
Secs. 23-42—23-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 23-67. - Definition. 
The compensation plan shall include: 
(1)  Current pay grade allocations for all classification categories in the classified service; 
(2)  A schedule of salary ranges consisting of minimum and maximum rates of pay with intermediate steps identified for all classes of positions; and 
(3)  The rules and policies contained in this article regulating pay rates and procedures. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-68. - Administration of the plan. 
The city manager shall be responsible for administering the compensation plan and setting personnel salaries in accordance with guidelines and policies established by the city council. In determining salaries the following factors shall be considered: 
(1)  Competency of the individual; 
(2)  Training and experience of the individual; 
(3)  Training and expertise required for the job; 
(4)  Salaries paid and fringe benefits provided to comparable municipal, county, state and private sector employees; 
(5)  Change in the cost of living in the area during the fiscal year; 
(6)  Any applicable state and federal laws and/or regulations; and 
(7)  The financial condition of the city. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-69. - Limitations on rates and increases. 
(a)  No employee may be compensated below the minimum step or above the maximum step of the pay grade range for his class of positions. 
(b)  All raises and increases are subject to the availability of funds and financial policies established by the mayor and city council. 
(c)  All merit increases granted shall be upon written recommendation of the respective department head and approval by the city manager. 
(d)  A salary increase given to any employee shall consist of no less than one and not more than two full steps in the salary range established for his grade. 
(e)  No employee shall receive more than a two-step salary increase in any fiscal year without prior written approval of the mayor and city council. This chapter does not apply to increases as a result of promotions, demotions or position reclassification. 
(f)  Salary adjustments approved after the first working day of a pay period shall become effective at the beginning of the next pay period or at such specific date as may be provided. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-70. - Appointment rate. 
The minimum (entry) rate of pay for a class shall be paid except for a qualified prospective employee or lack of available applicants at the minimum rate. The city manager may authorize employment above the minimum rate if appropriate. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-71. - Permanent status increase. 
An employee who successfully completes a probationary period following appointment or promotion may be granted a one step increase in salary. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-72. - Promotion rate. 
Promotion is movement from one class of positions to another classification with a higher salary grade and range. An employee who is promoted shall normally be advanced at least to the first step of the new range which constitutes an increase in salary and shall enter probation again for the new class. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-73. - Transfer rate. 
Transfer is movement from one position to another of the same or different classification with the same salary grade and range. An employee who is transferred will not normally receive an increase in salary and shall enter probation again for the new position. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-74. - Demotion rate. 
Demotion is movement from one class of positions to another classification having a lower salary grade and range. An employee who is demoted shall be reduced at least to the maximum rate of the new class or lower. A demotion may be voluntary or involuntary. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-75. - Reappointment rate. 
Reappointment is the rehiring of a permanent status employee who was separated while in good standing with the city. The reappointment rate shall normally be set at any step of the applicable range for the class that is not higher than the employee received at the time of separation. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-76. - Reclassification and reassignment rates. 
(a)  Reclassification. An employee whose position has been reclassified shall be compensated in the manner described under "promotion rate" or "demotion rate" as appropriate. 
(b)  Reassignment. An employee whose class is reassigned to a higher grade shall move to the first step of the new range which will constitute an increase in salary; provided, however, that the city manager may make additional adjustments based on circumstances. Reassignment to a lower grade is treated as a demotion. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 10)) 
Sec. 23-77. - Part-time work rate. 
Part time compensation rates are defined in the compensation plan for those job classifications which part time employment is allowed. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 11)) 
Sec. 23-78. - Overtime payment rate. 
(a)  This section shall not contravene the provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) pertaining to the minimum rate of compensation for employment in excess of an established workweek/period, excluding exempted positions. To be eligible for overtime pay, the employee must have actually been present at work for the specified number of hours except on council designated holidays. Personal leave will not count as hours worked for calculating overtime pay. 
(b)  The city's responsibility for payment of overtime is as follows: The city will generally compensate overtime at the rate of 1½ for hours worked in excess of the number of hours allowed per work week/period defined below: 
(1)  Nonexempt employees will be paid at the rate of 1½ for hours worked in excess of 40 hours per week. 
(2)  Sworn police officers (207(k) employees) will be paid at the rate of 1½ for hours worked in excess of 171 hours in a 28-day work period. 
(c)  Employees in positions determined to be "exempt" from the FLSA are not eligible for overtime pay. Compensatory time off may be granted in lieu of overtime payment if the employee so elects, and provided the city can reasonably accommodate time off without undue burden or interruption of vital services. No allowances whatsoever shall be made for overtime work not authorized and approved by the department head or city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 12)) 
Sec. 23-79. - Holiday payment rate. 
(a)  An employee who is not on approved leave and fails to report on a scheduled workday before or after a holiday shall not be paid for the holiday. Holidays which occur during approved annual or sick leave shall not be charged to annual or sick leave. 
(b)  Any regular, full time employee who is required to work on a council approved holiday shall receive pay for each hour worked plus holiday pay equal to each hour worked or eight hours, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 13)) 
Sec. 23-80. - On-call pay rate. 
Non-exempt employees who are on-call will be compensated at her standard rate of pay for two hours each day they are assigned as on-call. On-call hours are exempt and therefore do not contribute to the calculation of overtime pay. When an on-call employee responds to a call, hours worked begins once the employee starts working and will always be rounded up to the nearest quarter hour. The actual hours worked while on-call are not exempt and do contribute to the calculation of overtime pay. Actual hours worked while on-call also reduce the number of exempt hours each day by the number of hours worked. On-call employees will not be eligible to receive mileage/travel reimbursement for costs incurred in traveling to her assigned workplace. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 14)) 
Sec. 23-81. - Annual merit increase. 
With satisfactory performance and subject to the availability of funds, an employee may be granted a one step increase in salary at the beginning of any pay period he has served 12 months in the class since the last permanent status increase or annual increase was granted. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 15)) 
Sec. 23-82. - Special merit increase. 
The mayor and city council may grant additional special increases to employees in order to recognize exceptional performance or increased job skills and abilities, to correct errors or inequities, or for other job-related reasons. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 16)) 
Sec. 23-83. - Cost-of-living increase. 
At the discretion of the mayor and city council, employees may be given additional pay increases each year to offset the effects of inflation on real wages. Such increases shall not preclude eligibility for other salary increases. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 17)) 
Sec. 23-84. - Workers compensation payments. 
An employee who receives workers' compensation payments while receiving sick or annual leave benefit payments under these policies shall be required to endorse all such workers' compensation payments over to the city or shall have an equivalent amount deducted from his regular pay. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 18)) 
Sec. 23-85. - Termination pay. 
An employee who resigns or is terminated shall be paid for all accrued and unused annual leave provided he has turned in all city-owned equipment and property in his possession and has no outstanding liabilities to the city. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 19)) 
Sec. 23-86. - Payroll deduction. 
Deductions shall be made from each employee's salary, as required by law. Additional deductions may be made upon the request of the employee on determination by the city manager as to capability of payroll equipment, associated increase in workload and appropriateness of the deduction. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 3, § 20)) 
Secs. 23-87—23-112. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECRUITMENT, SELECTION AND APPOINTMENTS 

Sec. 23-113. - Applications. 
The city reserves the right to accept applications only for current job vacancies. In order for applicants to be considered for employment, a city employment application must be completed. Applicants may also attach a resume to the application; however, a resume will not be accepted in lieu of an application. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-114. - Hiring process. 
The city manager or personnel officer will administer and coordinate the hiring process for all position vacancies to ensure compliance with contractual, legal and equal opportunity requirements. All hiring efforts are conducted in the spirit of equal opportunity. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-115. - Recruitment and selection for vacant positions. 
(a)  Recruitment may be closed to consider only qualified current employees or may be open for public competition. When a vacancy occurs, a recruitment plan will be developed by the city manager and the department head based on current organizational needs. 
(b)  Vacancies shall be announced on public or employee bulletin boards, via newspapers and by other means to assure obtaining well qualified candidates for the positions. The announcement for the position shall specify the title, salary range, minimum qualification requirements, manner of making application, and final date on which applications will be accepted. Every reasonable effect shall be made to publicize vacancies so that all potential candidates are informed and all qualified persons are attracted to compete. 
(c)  The personnel officer shall provide the candidate with an application form which requires information covering training, experience and other job-related information. All applications must be signed by the applicant. Once a hiring decision is made the application forms for those individuals not hired shall be maintained as specified in the City of Emerson records retention schedule. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-116. - Pre-employment testing. 
Examinations may be developed for certain positions based on the position's responsibilities, the qualifications required, and resources available. The examination may consist of oral interview/application review, a structured questionnaire, practical tests, written tests, in-basket exercise, fitness test or assessment center, etc. In all cases, the testing will be job related and designed to determine the candidate's knowledge, skills and abilities for the position. The examination contents are developed by the affected department. Examination contents are confidential and unauthorized disclosure to any candidate is grounds for discipline. In certain situations, outside consultants may be contracted to assist with test development and/or examination. The department head shall ensure that all testing is based on bona fide occupational qualifications. The department head shall ensure that reasonable accommodations are made in test procedures to assure that persons with disabilities can be tested in an appropriate manner. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-117. - Qualification standards. 
Applicants, in order to qualify for a vacancy, shall meet the employment standards established by the position classification plan, applicable provisions of federal and state laws, and such other reasonable minimum standards as to character, aptitude, ability to meet the public, and physical condition as may be established by the mayor and city council with the advice and recommendation of the city manager and department heads; provided, however, that such minimum standards are necessary for satisfactory job performance and do not discriminate against individuals or groups in protected categories. Every effort shall be made to accept equivalent qualifications for minimum job standards when appropriate. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-118. - Types of appointments. 
When a person is employed or promoted, the personnel action form shall indicate that the employee has been given one of the following types of appointments: 
(1)  Probationary. The initial six-month or longer trial period of employment during which an employee is observed for effective job performance and completion of mandated state training if applicable. 
(2)  Temporary. Temporary appointments may be made to fill positions which are authorized and established for a specified period of time; when the city requires the service of one or more employees on a seasonal or intermittent basis; or in cases of emergency. Permanent status and other benefits or advantages of the personnel system, may not be earned while serving in this capacity unless specifically authorized by the city council. 
(3)  Regular. An employee serving a probationary appointment shall be given a regular appointment upon satisfactory completion of the probationary "working test" period. A probationary promotional appointment does not affect an employee's earned permanent status or employment rights acquired in another position. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-119. - Probationary period. 
(a)  The probationary period shall be regarded as an integral part of the selection process and shall be utilized for closely observing the employee's work, for securing the most effective adjustment of a new employee to his position and for rejecting any employee whose performance is not satisfactory. 
(b)  For new appointments and promotions, the probationary period shall normally be six months in duration. Public safety personnel who have not completed mandated state training during the first six months shall have their probationary period extended up to 12 months. If a department head requests an extension of the probationary period within ten days prior to expiration, the city manager may extend the duration of such period and expiration. No extension totaling more than one year shall be allowed. 
(c)  Only employees in permanent status are eligible for promotion. The probationary period for promotional appointments shall normally be six months. If a person is removed during the probationary period following a promotion, he shall be entitled to reemployment rights in the former class when a vacancy occurs. 
(d)  Evaluation of performance during probation: 
(1)  During the probationary period, the department head will frequently confer with the employee as to job-related goals and objectives for successful job performance and shall clearly communicate progress made and acceptability of work performance. The department head shall keep written records of all communication. At least ten days prior to the expiration of the probationary period, the department head shall notify the city manager in writing by designated form whether or not the employee has satisfactorily completed the probationary period. Prior to the expiration of the probationary period, the city manager shall notify the employee in writing as to whether or not he or she has successfully completed probation. 
(2)  Failure to send such a notice shall automatically grant the employee permanent status in the position. 
(3)  During the probationary period, a department head, with the prior approval of the city manager, may remove an employee who is unable and/or unwilling to perform the duties of the position satisfactorily or whose habits and dependability do not merit continued employment. The department head shall immediately report such intended removal to the city manager and his reasons. Upon approval by the city manager, the department head shall notify the employee and state the reasons for such action. Employees serving their probationary period do not have appeal rights unless there is alleged discrimination because of race, color, creed, sex, national origin, age or handicapped status, or unless the charges for dismissal could potentially damage the reputation of the employee sufficiently to warrant a name-clearing hearing to protect liberty interests. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-120. - Employee performance evaluations. 
(a)  The primary objectives of the employee performance evaluation system shall be to assess each employee's performance in relation to performance standards established for the job, to identify and document positive accomplishments, and to communicate any areas which are unsatisfactory or in need of improvement. The report of performance shall be used in determining eligibility for salary increases, as a basis in part for promotion, demotion, transfers, training, and dismissal or other types of discipline; and as a factor to consider in determining the order of layoffs. 
(b)  Evaluation process: 
(1)  All employees, except those exempted from the personnel system, shall be evaluated by their immediate supervisor and/or department head prior to the completion of probation and at least annually thereafter, and at any other time deemed appropriate. The department head shall furnish the completed report of performance to the city manager at least ten days prior to completion of the evaluation period. 
(2)  The report of performance shall be discussed directly with the employee. If an employee disagrees with the evaluation, he may submit a written statement which shall be attached to the evaluation form and forwarded to the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-121. - Fraud prohibited. 
No persons shall make any false statements, certificate, mark or report with regard to any application, test, certification or appointment made under any provision of these policies or in any matter commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing the impartial execution of this article and policies. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-122. - Payment for special treatment prohibited. 
No person shall, directly or indirectly, give, render, pay, offer, solicit or accept any money, service or other valuable consideration for any appointment, proposed appointment, promotion or proposed promotion to, or any advantage in, a position in the career service. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 4, § 10)) 
Secs. 23-123—23-148. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BENEFITS 

Sec. 23-149. - Group health insurance. 
The city offers to all its regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage and their eligible dependents group health coverage group health coverage. Premiums for all regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage may be paid in full by the city. Premiums for regular full time employees who wish to have dependent care coverage are paid at the same rate as for single coverage. Any amount due is the responsibility of the employee. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-150. - Group dental. 
The city offers to all its regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage and their eligible dependents group dental coverage. Premiums for all regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage may be paid in full by the city. Premiums for regular full time employees who wish to have dependent care coverage are paid at the same rate as for single coverage. Any amount due is the responsibility of the employee. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-151. - Group vision. 
The city offers to all its regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage and their eligible dependents group vision coverage. Premiums for all regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage may be paid in full by the city. Premiums for regular full time employees who wish to have dependent care coverage are paid at the same rate as for single coverage. Any amount due is the responsibility of the employee. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-152. - Life insurance. 
The city provides life insurance to all its regular full-time employees who meet the eligibility requirements as set forth by the city's insurance coverage. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-153. - Retirement system. 
(a)  The city is a member of the Georgia Municipal Association retirement plan. The city adheres to GMA's guidelines and procedures as adopted and/or updated. The city provides all regular full-time city employees a retirement program. Employees receive a defined benefit plan which is fully funded by the city. A regular full-time employee will be enrolled in the city's retirement program following one year of employment. 
(b)  A participant who meets the requirements of the city's retirement program, upon retirement on his normal retirement date, shall receive a monthly retirement benefit under which payments shall commence on the first day of the month coinciding with his normal retirement date and shall be payable on the first day of each month thereafter during his lifetime. The amount of the monthly retirement benefit of service shall be in accordance with the city's retirement program. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-154. - Social security. 
(a)  All employees are automatically included as participants in the social security system (FICA) which provides workers with the following benefits: retirement insurance, survivor's insurance, disability insurance, Medicare for the disabled and the aged, and supplemental security income. These benefits are in addition to public employees' retirement system benefits for which the employee may be eligible to receive. 
(b)  Financing of the program is accomplished by employee payroll deduction contributions and through a match paid by the city. Employee contributions stop each year once they have paid the required percentage as designated by the federal government. The salary limit and percentage are subject to change at the beginning of each year according to federal guidelines. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-155. - Unemployment compensation. 
The city is a covered employer under the unemployment compensation law. The basic objective of the program is to provide a partial replacement of wages for its employees during short periods of involuntary unemployment. The program is financed completely by the city. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-156. - Workers compensation.
