(a)  All employees are covered by worker's compensation, a program of industrial insurance to protect workers, their families and dependents from loss due to an injury caused by an accident arising out of and in the course of employment. The program provides for payment of medical and hospital bills, physical and vocational rehabilitation, and financial compensation while the worker is disabled, either temporarily or permanently, and is unable to work. It also provides for compensation for permanent partial disability such as the loss of a finger, eye, foot, etc., and assures death benefits and compensation to the worker's family or dependents in the event the injury is fatal. 
(b)  No compensation shall be allowed for the first seven calendar days of incapacity resulting from an injury, including the day of the injury, except the benefits provided for in O.C.G.A. § 34-9-200; however, if an employee is incapacitated for 21 consecutive days following an injury, compensation shall be paid for such first seven calendar days of incapacity. 
(c)  Generally, the average weekly wage over a 13-week period immediately preceding the injury shall be taken as the basis upon which to compute compensation. The city shall pay or cause to be paid a weekly benefit equal to two-thirds of the employee's average weekly wage but not more than $250.00 per week. Time spent on worker's compensation leave shall not be considered hours worked for purposes of leave accrual. An employee may be paid for earned sick leave while on worker's compensation leave. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-157. - Continuance of medical coverage (COBRA). 
(a)  In accordance with the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (COBRA), an employee and his or her dependents are entitled to elect to remain in the employer group health plan after it would normally end without proof of insurability. There will be no employer contributions for this extended coverage. The duration of coverage is as follows: 
(1)  Covered dependents who are terminated from the health plan because of divorce or death of the employee or Medicare—36 months; 
(2)  Covered dependent children who would lose coverage because of their ineligibility—36 months. 
(b)  Loss of coverage through: 
(1)  Reduction in hours—18 months; 
(2)  Termination (other than for gross misconduct)—18 months; 
(3)  Lay-off for economic reasons—18 months; 
(4)  Voluntary resignation—18 months. 
(c)  Employees and covered dependents who have been determined to be disabled under the Social Security Act may continue coverage for 29 months. The disability must exist prior to the date of the qualifying event and the member must provide notice of the disability determination to the employer within 18 months and no later than 60 days after the date of the Social Security Administration's determination. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-158. - Vehicles. 
(a)  The city may provide employees with vehicles to help them in carrying out their job efficiently and effectively. Employees shall not use a city vehicle for personal or private business. The only exception to this is commuting to and from work in a city vehicle. Use of a city vehicle for commuting must be authorized by the city manager for one of the following reasons: 
(1)  The employee responds to emergency or after hours calls; and 
(2)  The cost of providing the vehicle is less than the expense of mileage reimbursements for using a personal vehicle on city business; or 
(3)  The vehicle carries special equipment or personnel to respond to an emergency. Delays in getting this equipment or personnel to the scene of the emergency would result in increased danger to the public. 
(b)  The city may provide a vehicle or an allowance for the use of a personal vehicle as an additional fringe benefit for selected personnel. The criteria for providing such a benefit shall be: 
(1)  The city receives intangible benefits from giving the employee the vehicle benefit such as the speed of response to emergencies or after hours services which justify the benefit. 
(2)  Provision of the vehicle benefit is considered to be a part of the total pay package for the position. 
(3)  An employee who is provided an allowance for the use of a personal vehicle during official business may be covered by the city's vehicle insurance upon approval by the city manager and notification and approval is provided to the city by the city's insurer. 
(c)  Employees may not use a city vehicle for any personal use other than authorized commuting to and from work. Any further personal use of the vehicle may result in disciplinary action against the employee. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 10)) 
Sec. 23-159. - Educational enrichment. 
(a)  Upon the recommendation of the department head and the approval of the city manager, an employee may receive payment for the cost of tuition and books for any job-related course successfully completed. Such course shall be taken during employee off-duty hours unless it is necessary training for the job which is specifically approved by the department which involves travel; the city manager may also approve compensation based on regular city travel policies. 
(b)  Any employee who receives special training for his job qualifications through any private or governmental institution at the expense of the city and who thereafter within two years from receiving said special training terminates, either voluntarily or involuntarily, his employment with the city, shall repay to the city a pro rata part of such expense based upon the remaining balance of said two-year period. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 11)) 
Sec. 23-160. - Uniforms and equipment. 
Uniforms for police and fire department employees and such other employees as the city manager may authorize may be furnished by the city. Equipment deemed essential to job performance, including safety equipment, may also be furnished if authorized by the city manager. Employees are expected to maintain all uniforms and equipment in good condition, excluding normal wear, and turn in all items upon termination of employment. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 12)) 
Sec. 23-161. - Christmas bonus. 
The mayor and city council may authorize a Christmas bonus to both full time and part time employees. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 5, § 13)) 
Secs. 23-162—23-186. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HOLIDAYS AND LEAVES OF ABSENCE 

Sec. 23-187. - Holidays. 
(a)  Employees will receive the following paid holidays: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Martin Luther King's Birthday; 
(3)  Good Friday; 
(4)  Memorial Day; 
(5)  Fourth of July; 
(6)  Labor Day; 
(7)  Veterans Day; 
(8)  Thanksgiving Day; 
(9)  Day After Thanksgiving; 
(10)  Christmas Eve; 
(11)  Christmas Day. 
(b)  Other days may also be designated as paid holidays at the discretion of the city council. Whenever a holiday falls on Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be designated as substitute holiday and observed as the official holiday for that year. When the holiday falls on Sunday, the following Monday shall be designated as the official holiday for that year. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-188. - Annual (vacation) leave. 
The following provisions shall govern all terms and conditions of annual leave: 
(1)  Eligibility. All regular, full-time employees shall be entitled to accrue annual leave. Temporary, part-time, probationary or other exempt employees shall not be eligible for annual leave under these policies unless authorized by the city council. 
(2)  Rate of leave accrual. Employees will receive a paid vacation on the following basis: 
a.  One year of service — one-week vacation; 
b.  Two years of service — two weeks' vacation; 
c.  Ten years of service — three weeks' vacation; 
d.  Fifteen years of service — four weeks' vacation. 
(3)  Request for leave. A request for leave shall be submitted to the employee's immediate supervisor on a form designated by the city manager. Leave may be taken only after approval of the supervisor and/or the department head so that the department can function without hiring additional temporary help. 
(4)  Maximum allowable accumulation. Department heads shall encourage employees to utilize vacation leave and shall make every effort to allow for scheduled time off. Unused vacation leave not to exceed five (20) days or shifts may be carried forward into the next calendar year and all leave accumulated beyond five (20) days or shifts at the end of each year shall be subject to forfeiture unless the city manager authorized such excessive leave to be carried forward. Normally an employee may not be granted pay in lieu of vacation time off. Exceptions may be granted by the city manager and must be recommended by the department head. 
(5)  Payment for unused leave. An employee separated from the city service shall be paid at the regular rate for all unused annual leave provided he has turned in all city-owned equipment issued and has no other outstanding liabilities or debts to the city. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-189. - Sick leave. 
Employees accumulate sick leave at a rate of four hours per month for a total of six days per year. A medical certificate signed by a licensed physician may be required by a department head or the city manager to substantiate a request for sick leave for the following reasons: 
(1)  Any period of absence consisting of three or more consecutive working days. 
(2)  To support a request for sick leave during a period when the employee is on vacation leave. 
(3)  Leave of any duration if absence from duty recurs frequently or habitually, provided the employee has been notified or warned that a certificate will be required. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-190. - Family medical leave. 
(a)  The city will provide employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid family and medical leave during any 12-month period for the following: 
(1)  Birth, adoption or placement of a child for foster care. 
(2)  To care for a spouse, child or parent with a serious health condition or due to the disabling illness of the employee. 
(b)  To be eligible for leave, an employee must have worked for at least 12 months for the city and for a minimum of 1,250 hours during the previous year. Employees who take leave will be entitled to return to their positions, or positions with equivalent benefits, pay and other terms and conditions of employment. The city can deny a position to employees who are among the highest paid ten percent of the employees where the denial is necessary to prevent substantial and grievous economic injury to the operations of the city. 
(c)  Employees will not accrue any seniority or employment benefits during any period of leave. The city will provide coverage under a group health insurance plan for employees who are on leave under the same conditions as coverage would have been provided if no leave had been taken. Employees are required to provide at least 30 days' notice before beginning to take leave. 
(d)  Leave resulting from the birth of a child or the placement of a child for adoption or foster care cannot be taken intermittently or on a reduced leave schedule unless the employee and city agree. Leave resulting from the serious illness of a child, spouse, parent or the employee can be taken intermittently or on a reduced leave schedule when medically necessary. 
(e)  The city may require that any accrued personal leave of the employee be substituted for the 12 weeks of leave provided by the Federal Family and Medical Leave Act. Where leave is requested as a result of a serious health condition, the city can require the employee to provide a certification issued by a health care provider. The city can require an opinion from a second health care provider, which will be paid for by the city, where there is doubt as to the validity of the certification provided by the employee. If there is a conflict between the two opinions, the city may pay for an opinion by a third health care provider. The opinion of the third health care provider will be binding upon both the city and employee. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-191. - Military leave. 
(a)  The authority for this section is derived from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 38-2-279 and applies to all city employees who are affiliated with the United States Armed Forces, National Guard or Coast Guard. 
(b)  The city is obligated to release employees for service with the armed forces when the employee participates in: 
(1)  Annual training. 
(2)  Inactive duty training assemblies (weekend drills). 
(3)  Involuntary call-up. 
(c)  Ordered military duty shall result in no loss of seniority status or benefits which would have normally accrued if the employee had not been absent for such purposes. The city is obligated to grant military leave with pay to the employees for absences not exceeding 18 calendar days per year in accordance with state law. The city shall not require the employee to use personal leave for such purposes. The employee may, however, request use of personal leave, or leave without pay, to supplement absences exceeding those covered by the 18-day military leave allowance. 
(d)  The employee is responsible to provide to his department head copies of all military orders which will result in a leave of absence for military duty. Orders must specify the duties of absence, promulgation authority, letter order number and signature of issuing authority. Employees are required to notify their supervisors at the earliest possible date upon learning of scheduled military duty. Employees who fail to return to work on the date specified in the leave request without receiving an extension in advance are subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. Inactive duty training dates (weekend drills) should be provided to the department head as soon as available if the dates conflict with scheduled employment with the city. 
(e)  Extended leave of absence (exceeding 18 calendar day allowance) will be pursuant to the policy on leave of absence without pay. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-192. - Jury/court leave. 
(a)  Any regular full-time employee who is required to serve on a jury, or as a result of official city duties is required to appear before a court, legislative committee or quasi-judicial body as a witness in response to a subpoena or other directive, shall be allowed authorized leave with pay. A probationary employee called will have his probationary period extended to by the same amount of time as required for serving on jury duty. An employee who receives notice of jury duty or witness service must notify his supervisor immediately in order that arrangements may be made to cover the position. The city reserves the right to request that an employee who is called for jury be excused if their absence would create a hardship on the operational effectiveness of the department to which they are assigned. 
(b)  In order to receive full pay for the necessary time off duty, all such fees received by the employee (other than meal and travel allowance) must be deposited with the city clerk. City employees who perform jury duty or who are required to be a witness in a legal proceeding when such is required during periods when the employee is otherwise in a non-duty status will be permitted to retain all fees and allowances received therefore. 
(c)  Employees who appear in court as the plaintive or defendant in any action not related to their official duties shall not be paid for time away from work unless that time is accrued personal leave. 
(d)  Employees are to return to work after jury duty although no more than the regularly scheduled number of hours for both jury duty and work shall be required. If excused as a juror on any given day, the employee is expected to contact the department head and to report to work as instructed. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-193. - Bereavement leave. 
A regular full time employee who has a member of his immediate family taken by death shall receive up to three days off with pay as bereavement leave to arrange and/or attend funeral activities. If additional time is necessary, it shall be taken as annual leave or unpaid leave if annual leave has been exhausted with authorization of the appropriate department head and city manager. Time for attendance at the funeral of others may be granted using annual leave, leave without pay or made up within the same pay period. The employee must notify his immediate supervisor upon making determination to take time off from work. Employees who fail to return to work on the date specified to the department head without receiving an extension are subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-194. - Workers compensation and use of leave. 
(a)  An employee who is temporarily disabled because of injury or illness sustained directly in the performance of his work is covered by the provision of the State Workers Compensation Act. Such injury or illness must be reported immediately or as soon as possible thereafter to the employee's supervisor. 
(b)  An employee receiving workers' compensation payments who has elected to use sick or annual leave shall be required to endorse such payments over to the city or have an equivalent deduction made from his regular rate of pay, whichever option is preferred by the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-195. - Leave of absence without pay. 
Requests for leave of absence without pay shall be in writing and shall state specifically the reasons for the request, the date desired to begin the leave, and the date of return. The request shall normally be submitted by the employee to the affected department head. The department head shall confer with the city manager and grant, modify or deny the request based upon the best interest of the city, giving due consideration to the reasons given by the employee, and the requirements of any applicable state and federal laws. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 6, § 9)) 
Secs. 23-196—23-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EMPLOYEE RESPONSIBILITIES, ETHICS AND CONDUCT 

Sec. 221. - Hours of work. 
(a)  The normal working hours for employees shall be as scheduled by the various department heads, with such schedule to be established so that the needs of the department to deliver services to the citizens are met. Such schedule shall be approved by the city manager. Employees are expected to be at their work location and ready to begin work at the beginning of their work schedule. The meal periods should be scheduled to allow for continuous staffing of offices, when applicable, with at least one person, except where more personnel are required to be on duty. 
(b)  Hours for part-time and certain other employees may vary from the normal office hours noted above due to the nature of their duties and will be determined by the appropriate department head, with concurrence of the city manager. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-222. - Work periods. 
This section shall not apply to executive, professional, administrative and all other employees who are exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act. The following work periods may be changed to accommodate special work schedules, such as summer maintenance schedules: 
(1)  The work period for any sworn police officer shall be 28 days. All sworn officers will be scheduled for an average of 171 hours per 28-day period. 
(2)  The work period for all other city employees shall be a seven-day period beginning on Friday at 12:01 a.m. and continuing to Thursday at 12:00 a.m. (midnight). The minimum work week for full-time employees shall be 40 hours. 
(3)  With respect to 207(k) employees, where hours worked are not in excess of the applicable maximum hours standard, the city may give the employee time off for the hours worked in excess of those normally scheduled. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-223. - Attendance and records. 
(a)  Each department head shall be responsible for the punctual attendance of all persons in the department. Daily attendance records will be maintained and submitted by each department, including the date and time of each absence and the reason for each absence. Attendance shall be a consideration in determining promotions, transfers, satisfactory completion of probationary periods, and continued employment with the city. Frequent tardiness or other attendance irregularities shall be cause for disciplinary action. 
(b)  Advance notice of anticipated tardiness is expected; notice of unavoidable tardiness is expected when possible. Failure to do so will be construed as an unexcused absence, and the day missed will not be paid. Tardiness must be made up during the pay period in which it occurs. Notification by another employee, friend or relative is not considered proper except in an emergency situation where the employee is physically unable to make the notification. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-224. - Employment of relatives. 
Two or more members of an immediate family shall not be employed within the same department. The term "immediate family" shall include spouse, mother, father, sister, brother, son, daughter, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandmother, grandfather, grandson, granddaughter, stepson, and stepdaughter. This section shall not apply retroactively to any employee actively employed before the adoption of this provision. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-225. - Outside employment. 
No employee may engage in any paid outside employment which interferes with the efficient performance of his duties and/or presents a conflict of interest. All outside employment must be reported to the department head and authorized by the city manager. When outside employment creates a conflict of interest situation between the employee and the city, resignation from one of the positions held will be expected. Failure to comply with this rule will constitute grounds for dismissal. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-226. - Gifts and gratuities. 
An employee shall not accept gifts, gratuities or loans from organizations, business concerns or individuals with whom he has official business. These limitations do not prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally, nor do they prohibit employees from obtaining loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that enforcement officers, inspectors and those involved in purchasing and the collection and expenditure of funds guard against relationships which might be construed as evidence of favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. Violations of this rule will result in disciplinary action. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-227. - Political activity. 
(a)  No city employee shall be appointed, promoted, demoted, favored or discriminated against with respect to employment in the personnel system because of his political opinions or affiliations. 
(b)  No person shall use or promise to use, any official authority or influence to secure an appointment or advantage in appointment to a position in the personnel system or an increase in pay or other advantage in employment with the purpose of influencing the vote or political action of that individual. 
(c)  No employee in the personnel system shall solicit, take part in soliciting, pay or promise to pay an assessment for political purposes, subscription, contribution or service. 
(d)  No employee in the personnel system shall hold or seek an elective office. Any employee seeking elective office shall resign or be separated from employment with the city. 
(e)  The employee has the right to contribute to, hold membership in, serve as an officer of, support a political party, vote, support or campaign for city, county, state or national political candidates, express privately opinions on all political subjects and candidates, maintain political neutrality, or attend political meetings. 
(f)  Exception to subsection (e) of this section: Any city employee who, as a normal and foreseeable incident to his principal job or position, performs duties in connection with an activity financed in whole or in part by federal loans or grants, comes under the federal Hatch Act which prohibits the following: 
(1)  Use of official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with an election or nomination for office, or affecting the result thereof. 
(2)  Directly or indirectly coercing, attempting to coerce, commanding or advising any other such officer or employee to pay, lend or contribute any part of his salary of compensation or anything else of value to any party, committee, organization, agency or person for political purposes. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-228. - State driver's license and use of vehicles. 
(a)  Employees driving city vehicles are required to have such driver's licenses for the vehicles being driven as are required by state law, irrespective of whether the employee drives the vehicle on a regular, occasional or other basis, and whether or not this requirement is included or omitted in the description of the class to which the employee was appointed. Violations, citations, fines or other actions taken by any police jurisdiction against any employee while driving a city vehicle in violation of this rule shall be the responsibility of the employee and may be cause for disciplinary action. 
(b)  Anyone misusing or abusing city vehicles, using a city vehicle for other than approved purposes, or taking a vehicle home when not approved by the city manager shall be subject to appropriate disciplinary action, including dismissal if deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-229. - Harassment/sexual harassment prohibited. 
(a)  The city prohibits, and will not tolerate, sexual harassment or harassment on the basis of race, gender, age, religion, color, national origin, age or disability. Harassment complaints or allegations will be investigated promptly and where it is determined that such inappropriate conduct has occurred, we will act immediately to eliminate the conduct and impose such corrective action as is necessary, including disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. 
(b)  Sexual harassment is defined as unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature when: 
(1)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual's employment; 
(2)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis for employment decisions affecting such individual; or 
(3)  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. 
(c)  Harassment, other than sexual, is verbal or physical conduct that denigrates or shows hostility or aversion towards an individual because of race, color, religion, gender, national origin, age, or disability, which has the purpose or effect of creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive work environment or unreasonably interferes with an individual's work performance or otherwise adversely affects an individual's employment opportunities. Harassing conduct includes, but is not limited to, epithets, slurs, negative stereotyping, or threatening, intimidating, hostile acts. Written or graphic material which denigrates or indicates hostility or aversion toward an individual or group is prohibited from display on the employer's premises, or circulation in the workplace. 
(d)  Any employee who feels harassed or who knows of or suspects the occurrence of forbidden harassment is responsible for informing the department head or city manager, preferably in writing, of the facts regarding such harassment so that management may promptly and thoroughly conduct an investigation. Department heads who receive a harassment complaint are to contact the city manager immediately. 
(e)  If an investigation confirms that unlawful harassment occurred, the city will take immediate corrective action, including discipline up to and including immediate termination of employment of the harassing party as is appropriate. Employees making complaints of sexual harassment are protected against retaliation from alleged harassers or other employees. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-230. - Work place safety. 
Safety is the responsibility of both the city and employees. It is the policy of the city to establish a safe work environment for employees. Department heads shall establish a safety program including policies and procedures regarding safety practices and precautions and training in safety methods for their departments. Employees shall follow the safety policies and procedures and attend safety training programs as a condition of employment. Employees who violate such policies and procedures shall be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 10)) 
Sec. 23-231. - City property, personal property and privacy limitations. 
(a)  The city may furnish desks, closets and/or lockers for security of employee coats, purses and other personal possessions. The city does not, however, assume responsibility for any theft or damage to the personal belongings of employees. 
(b)  Employees should have no expectation of privacy when using such or any other city property. The city regards desks, closets, lockers, work spaces, computers, file cabinets and files, city vehicles, furniture and other city property, as well as data, programs, communications, messages and other property created on, acquired by, developed for or located in any city facility or equipment, either in printed or digital format, as city property. The city reserves the right to search the same, including any personal possessions contained in there when it determines that there is a security, health, or other appropriate reason to do so. Such reasons may include, without limitation, the following: the need to locate city property; health or safety concerns; reasonable suspicion of misconduct; termination of employee; or for other business- related purposes. The city reserves the right to review the contents of any document or communication, created or stored on a city computer or phone system, including electronic mail, text messaging, and voicemail. Employees do not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in these areas or in any other city work areas or when using city equipment. 
(c)  City equipment is provided at public expense to assist employees in carrying out official city business. While personal use of city equipment is prohibited, it is recognized that certain de minimis use may occur, e.g., the receipt of a personal phone call on a city-owned phone. It is the employee's responsibility to ensure the city incurs no cost as a result of personal use of city equipment. Inappropriate or excessive use of city equipment for personal purposes may subject the employee to disciplinary action, up to and including termination. 
(d)  The city recognizes that employees may need or want to bring personal property to work. The city permits employees to do so but asks its employees to refrain from bringing unnecessary or inappropriate personal property to the workplace. Any property that is not appropriate for the conduct of normal business, that may be disruptive to workflow, may pose a safety risk to employees or the public, or which violates the terms of any city policy may be considered unnecessary or inappropriate. It will be within the city's sole discretion to determine whether certain personal property is unnecessary or inappropriate. 
(e)  It is the employee's responsibility to safeguard personal belongings. The city will not be liable for lost, damaged or stolen property of its employees and at no time will the city replace or reimburse an employee for personal property that an employee brings to the workplace. Employees are encouraged to exercise reasonable care to safeguard personal items brought to work. For example, employees should not bring valuables to work and should not leave personal items where they might be damaged or stolen. Improper or excessive use of personal property brought onto city property or worksites or during work hours (for example, the excessive or inappropriate use of personal cell phones for personal phone calls, text-messaging, imaging or videotaping), may also result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 11)) 
Sec. 23-232. - Internet and email policy. 
(a)  The city furnishes computers for employees' use in conducting city business. This includes access to e-mail and the Internet. The Internet contains many useful features, including e-mail to non-city resources, access to research materials, and information exchange. The purpose of this chapter is to establish basic rules for employees' use of the city's computer system, including the Internet and Internet e-mail. 
(b)  The Internet can be misused in a variety of ways, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Downloading files that contain viruses, thereby endangering city information services; 
(2)  Accessing objectionable material; 
(3)  Wasting work time by performing unauthorized research or accessing non-business related information and people or for computer games, or online games. 
(c)  An employee does not have a right to privacy when using the Internet via city resources and employees should not expect or assume any privacy regarding the content of email communications. The city reserves the express right to monitor and inspect the activities of the employee while accessing the Internet at any time, and to read, use and disclose e-mail messages. In addition, all software, files, information, communications, and messages (including e-mails) downloaded or sent via the Internet using city resources are the city's records and property of the city; such records are subject to potential review and disclosure under the Georgia Open Records Laws. Even after an email message has been "deleted," it may still be possible to retrieve it. 
(d)  Internet use via city resources is for city business. Except as outlined here, use of city's computer, Internet and email services are for city business only. Some limited personal use is permitted, so long as it does not result in cost to the city, does not interfere with the performance of duties, is brief in duration and frequency, does not distract from the conduct of city business and does not compromise the security or integrity of city information or software. Such limited use should not occur on "paid time," but is permitted immediately before or after work hours and during an employee's breaks. Examples of allowable personal use include accessing a weather report or news item on the Internet, or transmitting e-mail to a family member to assure safe arrival at home. Any personal use of the city's computer, Internet and email services must comply with all applicable laws and city policies, including anti-discrimination policies and Internet usage policy. Internet use must comply with applicable laws and city policies including but not limited to all federal and state laws, and city policies. 
(e)  The city has the capability and reserves the right to access, review, copy, modify and delete any information transmitted through or stored in its computer system. The city may disclose all such information to any party (inside or outside the city) it deems appropriate and in accordance with applicable law. Accordingly, employees should not use the computer system to send, receive or store any information they wish to keep private. Employees should treat the computer system like a shared file system-with the expectation that files sent, received or stored anywhere in the system will be available for review by any authorized representative of the city for any purpose, as well as the public if a proper request is made for public records. 
(e)  Good judgment should always be employed in using the city's e-mail and Internet systems. Employee e-mail messages may be read by someone other than the person(s) to whom they were sent. E-mail inconsistent with the city's policies must be avoided. For example, it is prohibited to make jokes or comments which could offend someone on the basis of gender, race, age, religion, national origin, disability or sexual orientation. These comments would be in direct conflict with the city's policies prohibiting discrimination and harassment. Accordingly, employees should create and send only courteous, professional and businesslike messages that do not contain objectionable offensive or potentially discriminatory material. 
(f)  The safety and security of the city's network and resources must be considered at all times when using the Internet. Any programs from a non-current source (i.e., software that is not purchased in original diskette or CD ROM format) or which involve executable or binary files must not be downloaded or installed without prior permission from the city manager or his designee without being properly scanned for viruses. Employees are not to share or reveal individual passwords to anyone other than the city manager or his designee. 
(g)  Internet users are responsible for complying with this and all other city policies when using the city's resources for accessing the Internet. Violation of this chapter is grounds for disciplinary action, up to and including termination. The city manager has the right to restrict or prohibit any employee from Internet access for violation of the policies set forth. 
(h)  Nothing in this chapter prohibits the use and access of the described systems for bona fide law enforcement and investigation purposes. 
(i)  Sending unencrypted primary account numbers by end-user messaging technologies such as email, instant messaging, chat or text is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 12)) 
Sec. 23-233. - Wireless communication devices. 
(a)  Wireless communications devices include, but are not limited to, cellular telephones, wireless handheld devices and pagers. An employee's personal communications using city wireless communications devices should be limited, and employees are expected to exercise sound judgment in both the duration and frequency of such use. These devices should not be treated as if they were the employee's personal property. As with similar city property, such as telephones, although minor personal use of wireless communications devices is not prohibited by this chapter, it must not interfere with the performance of the employee's work duties or normal business operations of the city. Employees must reimburse the city for costs that would not otherwise have been incurred by the city resulting from the employee's personal use of such devices. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to monitor the use of all city-owned wireless devices. Reasonable precautions should be made to prevent equipment theft, vandalism, and improper use of wireless device equipment and services. 
(c)  Employee use of a personal wireless device shall be governed by and consistent with the guidelines provided for city-owned wireless devices, if the employee-owned wireless device is used for official city business and reimbursement is requested. Use of an employee-owned wireless device for city business should be limited to emergencies and situations where alternative means of communication are unsafe, inconvenient, or not readily available. Additionally use of an employee-owned wireless device for personal use while on duty shall be limited in use. Excessive use will be grounds for discipline. 
(d)  Employees should recognize that cellular transmissions are not secure; thus, employees should exercise discretion when relating confidential information during a cellular telephone call. 
(e)  Employees violating this chapter are subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 13)) 
Sec. 23-234. - Seat belt policy 
Anyone operating or riding in city owned vehicles must wear a seat belt at all times. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 7, § 14)) 
Secs. 23-235—23-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ALCOHOL AND DRUG POLICY 

Sec. 23-261. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city provides a range of services to its residents. Part of the city's mission is to ensure that these services are delivered safely and efficiently by establishing and maintaining a drug- and alcohol-free work environment which promotes the health and safety of employees and the public. In keeping with this mission, the city declares that the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensing, possession, or use of controlled substances or the misuse of alcohol is prohibited for all those employees performing functions which can cause injury to person or damage to property (safety-sensitive functions). 
(b)  Additionally, the purpose of this chapter is to establish guidelines to maintain a drug and alcohol free workplace in compliance with the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988 and all other relevant mandates and laws of the state and the federal government. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 1)) 
Sec. 23-262. - Applicability. 
This Drug and Alcohol Testing Policy applies to all employees (full- and part-time, paid or volunteer) and includes, but is not limited to, employees operating a vehicle owned, leased or routinely used by the city; maintaining any vehicle operated by the city for city business (regardless of ownership); protecting persons and property; ensuring health and sanitation; operating and maintaining buildings and other facilities owned or leased by the city; and all other functions and services performed or provided by the city which have the potential to injure persons or damage property (safety-sensitive functions). 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 2)) 
Sec. 23-263. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accident. An occurrence associated with the performance of the work, including the operation of a vehicle, if, as a result: 
(1)  A person dies; 
(2)  A person suffers a bodily injury and immediately receives medical treatment away from the scene of the accident; or 
(3)  One or more vehicles incurs disabling damage as the result of the occurrence and is transported away from the scene by a tow truck or other vehicle. For purposes of this definition, disabling damage is damage which prevents departure of any vehicle from the scene of an accident in its usual manner in daylight after simple repairs. Disabling damage includes damage to vehicles that could have been operated, but would have been further damage if so operated. Disabling damage does not include damage which can be remedied temporarily at the scene of the accident without special tools or parts, e.g., tire disablement without other damage even if no spare tire is available, or damage to headlights, taillights, turn signals, horn, mirrors, or windshield wipers that renders them inoperable. 
Adulterated specimen. A specimen that contains a substance that is not expected to be present in human urine, or contains a substance expected to be present, but is at a concentration so high it is not consistent with human urine. 
Alcohol. The intoxicating agent in beverage alcohol, ethyl alcohol, or other low molecular weight alcohols contained in any beverage, mixture, mouthwash, candy, food, preparation, or medication. 
Alcohol concentration: expressed in terms of grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath as measured by an evidential breath testing device. 
Cancelled test. A drug test that has been declared invalid by a Medical Review Officer (MRO). A cancelled test is neither positive nor negative. 
Department of Transportation (DOT). Department of the federal government which includes the Federal Transit Administration, Federal Railroad Administration, Federal Highway Administration, Federal Motor Carriers' Safety Administration, Research and Special Programs and the Office of the Secretary of Transportation. 
Designated Employer Representative (DER). An employee authorized by the city to take immediate action to prevent employees from performing their job unsafely and to make required decisions regarding testing. The DER also receives test results and other communications for the city, consistent with the requirements of 49 CFR Parts 40, as amended and 655. 
Dilute specimen. A specimen with creatinine and specific gravity values that are lower than expected for human urine. 
Disabling damage. Damage which prevents departure of any vehicle from the scene of the occurrence in its usual manner in daylight after simple repairs. Disabling damage includes damage to vehicles that could have been operated, but would have been further damaged if so operated, but does not include damage which can be remedied temporarily at the scene of the occurrence without special tools or parts, tire disablement without other damage, even if no spare tire is available, or damage to headlights, taillights, turn signals, horn, mirrors or windshield wipers that makes them inoperable. 
Employee. Any employee of the city, whether full time or part-time, paid or volunteer, and successful applicants for any city position, prior to commencement of employment. 
Evidentiary Breath Testing Device (EBT). A device approved by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) for the evidential testing of breath at 0.02 and 0.04 alcohol concentrations. Approved devices are listed in the NHTSA conforming products list. 
Medical Review Officer (MRO). A licensed physician (medical doctor or doctor of osteopathy) responsible for receiving laboratory results generated by the drug testing program who has knowledge of substance abuse disorders and has appropriate medical training to interpret and evaluate an individual's confirmed positive test result, together with the person's medical history, and any other bio-medical information. 
Negative dilute. A drug test which is negative for the five drug/drug metabolites, but has a specific gravity value lower than expected for human urine. 
Negative test result. For a drug test, a verified presence of the identified drug or its metabolite below the minimum levels specified in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended; for an alcohol test, an alcohol concentration of less than 0.02 Blood Alcohol Content (BAC). 
Non-negative test result. A test result found to be adulterated, substitute, invalid, or positive for drug/drug metabolites. 
Positive test result. For a drug test, a verified presence of the identified drug or its metabolite at or above the minimum levels specified in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended; for an alcohol test, a confirmed alcohol concentration of 0.04 BAC or greater. 
Prohibited drug. Marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines, phencyclidine at levels above the minimum thresholds specified in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. 
Safety-sensitive functions include operating a vehicle owned or leased by the city, maintaining any vehicle operated by the city for city business (regardless of ownership), carrying a firearm for purposes of security or law enforcement, protecting people and property from fire, using equipment which can injure people or damage property in areas where other employees or the general public are present, and ensuring the quality and availability of water. 
Substance abuse professional (SAP). A licensed physician (medical doctor or doctor of osteopathy) or licensed or certified psychologist, social worker, employee assistance professional, or addiction counselor (certified by the National Association of Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Counselors Certification Commission or by the International Certification Reciprocity Consortium/Alcohol and other Drug Abuse) with knowledge of and clinical experience in the diagnosis and treatment of drug and alcohol related disorders. 
Substituted specimen. A specimen with creatinine and specific gravity values that are so diminished that they are not consistent with normal human urine. 
Test refusal. The following are considered a refusal to be tested if the employee: 
(1)  Fails to appear for any test (except pre-employment) within a reasonable time, as determined by the city, after being directed by the city to do so; 
(2)  Fails to remain at the testing site until the testing process is complete; 
(3)  Fails to provide a urine or breath specimen for any drug or alcohol test required by the city or by 49 CFR Part 40, as amended; 
(4)  In the case of a directly observed or monitored collection in a drug test, fails to permit the observation or monitoring of his provision of the specimen; 
(5)  Fails to provide a sufficient amount of urine or breath when directed and it is determined, through a required medical evaluation, that there was no adequate medical explanation for the failure; 
(6)  Fails or declines to take a second test the city or the collector of the specimen has directed the employee to take; 
(7)  Fails to undergo a medical examination or evaluation, as directed by the MRO as part of the verification process, or as directed by the DER as part of the "shy bladder" or "shy lungs" procedures; 
(8)  Fails to cooperate with any part of the testing process (e.g., refusing to empty pockets when requested, behaving in a confrontational or threatening manner so as to disrupt the testing process); 
(9)  Fails or refuses to sign associated testing documents; 
(10)  Test refusal also includes providing an adulterated or substituted specimen. 
Verified negative test. A test result reviewed by the MRO and determined to have no evidence of prohibited drug use above the minimum cutoff levels specified in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. 
Verified positive test. A test result reviewed by the MRO and determined to have evidence of prohibited drug use above the minimum cutoff levels specified in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. 
Validity testing. The evaluation of the specimen to determine if it is consistent with normal human urine. The purpose of validity testing is to determine whether certain adulterants or foreign substances were added to the urine, if the urine was diluted, or if the specimen was substituted. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 3)) 
Sec. 23-264. - Education and training. 
(a)  Every employee (including full time and part-time employees and volunteers) will receive a copy of this chapter and will have access to the corresponding federal regulations, including 49 CFR Parts 40, as amended, and 655. In addition, all employees will undergo a minimum of 60 minutes of training on the signs and symptoms of drug use, including the effects and consequences of drug use on personal health, safety, and the work environment. The training also includes manifestations and behavioral cues which may indicate prohibited drug use. 
(b)  All supervisory personnel who are in a position to determine employee fitness for duty will receive 60 minutes of reasonable suspicion training on the physical, behavioral, and performance indicators of probable drug use and 60 minutes of additional reasonable suspicion training on the physical, behavioral, speech, and performance indicators of probable alcohol misuse. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 4)) 
Sec. 23-265. - Prohibited substances. 
Prohibited substances addressed by this chapter include the following: 
(1)  Illegally used controlled substances or drugs under the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988; 
(2)  Controlled Substance Act (21 U.S.C. 812) as further defined by 21 CFR 1300.11 through 1300.15 is prohibited in the workplace at all times (unless the employee has a legal prescription for the drug or substance). Consequently, employees may be tested at any time they are on duty. These drugs and substances include, but are not limited to marijuana, amphetamines, opiates, phencyclidine, cocaine, and any drug not approved for medical use by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency or the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. 
(3)  Illegal use includes use of any illegal drug, misuse of any legally prescribed drugs and use of illegally obtained prescription drugs. Also, the medical use of marijuana or the use of hemp-related products which cause drug or drug metabolites to be present in the human body above the minimum thresholds is a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 5)) 
Sec. 23-266. - Legal drugs. 
The appropriate use of legally prescribed drugs taken as prescribed and non-prescription medications is not prohibited. However, the use of any substance, drug or medication which carries a warning label stating that mental functioning, motor skills, or judgment may be affected must report his use to his supervisor and must provide a written release from his doctor or pharmacist indicating that the employee is capable of safely performing his job. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 6)) 
Sec. 23-267. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  All employees are prohibited from reporting for duty or remaining on duty whenever there is a quantifiable presence of a prohibited drug in his body above the minimum thresholds defined in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. All employees are prohibited from consuming alcohol while on the job (including immediately prior to reporting to work and during meal and break times) or while on call. If an on call employee has consumed alcohol, he must acknowledge the use of alcohol at the time he is called to report for work or submit to an alcohol test if the employee maintains his ability to perform the work. The city shall not permit the employee to perform or continue to perform work if it has actual knowledge that the employee is using alcohol. 
(b)  All employees are prohibited from reporting to work or remaining at work while having a BAC of 0.02 or greater. No employee shall consume alcohol for eight hours following involvement in an accident, or until he submits to a post-accident drug/alcohol test, whichever occurs first. No employee shall consume alcohol within four hours of performing work which has the potential to injure people or property. 
(c)  Employees shall not manufacture, distribute, dispense, possess, or use prohibited substances in the work place. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 7)) 
Sec. 23-268. - Drug statute conviction. 
Consistent with the Drug Free Workplace Act of 1988, all employees are required to notify their management of any criminal statute conviction for a violation occurring in the workplace within five days after such conviction. Failure to comply with this provision shall result in termination. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 8)) 
Sec. 23-269. - Testing requirements. 
(a)  Analytical urine drug testing and breath testing for alcohol will be conducted as required by 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. All employees shall be subject to testing prior to being officially hired by the city, as well as for testing for reasonable suspicion, after certain accidents, and randomly, as defined in this chapter and return-to-work/follow-up testing. 
(b)  All employees who have tested positive for prohibited substances, abuse of prescription drugs, or alcohol and who have successfully completed a treatment program recommended by the SAP and have been released to return to work will be tested prior to returning to work. Additionally, for a period of from one to five years after returning to work, follow-up testing will occur, including at least six tests within the first year. The duration of the testing period and the frequency of tests will be determined by the SAP. 
(c)  A drug test may occur any time an employee is on duty. An alcohol test may occur immediately before, during, or immediately after the performance of any work with the potential to injure any person (including the employee, other employees, or the general public) or damage any property. 
(d)  All employees will be subject to urine drug testing and breath alcohol testing as an ongoing condition of employment with the city. Any employee who refuses to comply with a request for testing shall be removed from work and his employment terminated. Any employee who is suspected of providing false information in connection with a drug test or who is suspected of falsifying test results through tampering, contamination, adulteration, or substitution shall be required to undergo an observed collection. Upon determining that an employee has engaged in one or more of these behaviors, the employee shall be removed from duty and his employment with the city shall be terminated. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 9)) 
Sec. 23-270. - Drug testing procedures. 
(a)  Testing shall be conducted in such a manner as to assure a high degree of accuracy and reliability, using techniques, equipment, and laboratory facilities approved by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). All testing will be conducted consistent with the procedures set forth in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. The testing will be performed in a private, confidential manner and every effort will be made to protect the employee, the integrity of the drug testing procedure, and the validity of the test result. 
(b)  The drugs that will be tested for are marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines, and phencyclidine. After the identity of the donor (employee) is checked using picture identification, a urine specimen will be collected using the split specimen collection method described in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. Each specimen will be accompanied by a DOT Chain of Custody and Control Form and identified using a unique identification number that matches the specimen with the person being tested. The specimen analysis will be performed at a HHS-certified laboratory. An initial drug screen and validity test will be performed on the primary urine specimen. For those specimens which are not negative, a confirmatory Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (GM/MS) test will be performed. A specimen will be considered positive if the amount of drug(s)/drug metabolite(s) identified by the GM/MS test are above the minimum thresholds established in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. 
(c)  The test result from the HHS-certified laboratory will be reported to the MRO. The MRO will review the test results to ensure the scientific validity of the test and will determine whether there is a legitimate medical explanation for a confirmed positive, substitute, or adulterated test result. The MRO will attempt to contact the employee to notify the employee of the non-negative test result and provide the employee an opportunity to explain the confirmed test result. The MRO will then review the employee's medical history/medical records, as appropriate, to determine whether there is a legitimate medical explanation for a non-negative test result. If no legitimate medical explanation is found, the test will be verified positive or classified as a refusal to test and reported to the DER. If a legitimate explanation is found, the MRO will report the test result as negative to the DER and no further action will be taken. If the test is determined to be invalid and there is no medical explanation, a retest will be performed under direct observation. 
(d)  Any employee who questions the results of a required drug test may request that the split sample be tested. The split specimen test will be performed at a second HHS-certified laboratory which has no affiliation with the laboratory that analyzed the primary specimen. This second test shall be conducted on the split sample which was provided by the employee at the same time as the primary sample. The method of collecting, storing, and testing the split sample will be consistent with the procedures set forth in 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. The employee's request for a split sample test must be made to the MRO within 72 hours after the employee receives notice of a verified positive test result from the primary sample. Requests occurring more than 72 hours of notification will only be accepted at the discretion of the MRO if the delay was due to actual circumstances which were beyond the employee's control. The city will pay for the split sample test to ensure prompt analysis of the sample; however, the city will seek reimbursement from the employee for the costs of the split sample test. 
(e)  If the analysis of the split specimen fails to confirm the presence of the drug(s) detected in the primary specimen, if the split sample cannot be analyzed, or if the results of the split sample are not scientifically adequate, the MRO will declare the original test to be cancelled and will direct the city to retest the employee under direct observation. 
(f)  The split sample will be stored at the laboratory at which the initial sample was analyzed. If the primary specimen is negative, the split will be discarded. If the primary specimen is positive, the split will be retained for testing if the employee requests the MRO to arrange for split specimen testing. If the primary specimen is positive, it will be retained in frozen storage for one year and the split specimen will also be retained for one year. 
(g)  Consistent with 49 CFR Part 40, as amended, collection under direct observation by a person of the same gender as the employee and with no advance notice will occur if: 
(1)  The laboratory reports to the MRO that a specimen is invalid and the MRO reports to the DER that there was not an adequate medical explanation for the result; 
(2)  The MRO reports to the DER that the original positive, adulterated, or substituted test result had to be cancelled because the test of the split specimen could not be performed; 
(3)  The collector observes materials brought into the collection site or the employee's conduct clearly indicates an attempt to tamper with the specimen; or 
(4)  The temperature of the original specimen was out of the range normal for human urine. 
(h)  In addition, the DER may request a collection under direct observation of an employee if the drug test is a return to duty test or a follow-up test. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 10)) 
Sec. 23-271. - Alcohol testing procedures. 
(a)  Tests for breath alcohol concentration will be conducted using a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) - approved Evidential Breath Testing device (EBT) operated by a trained Breath Alcohol Technician (BAT). Alcohol screening tests may also be performed using a non-evidential testing device approved by NHTSA. If the initial test indicates an alcohol concentration of 0.02 or greater, a second test will be performed to confirm the results of the initial test. The confirmatory test must be performed by a BAT using an EBT at least 15 minutes, but no more than 30 minutes, after completing the initial test. 
(b)  The EBT will identify each test by a unique, sequential identification number. This number, time, and unit identifier will be provided on each EBT printout. The EBT printout, along with an approved alcohol testing form, will be used to document the test, subsequent results, and identity of the employee tested. The test will be performed in a private, confidential manner, as required by 49 CFR Part 40, as amended. The testing procedure will be followed as prescribed to protect the employee and to maintain the integrity of the alcohol testing procedures and the validity of the test result. 
(c)  A confirmed alcohol concentration of 0.04 or greater will be considered a positive alcohol test result and in violation of this chapter. Test results confirming an alcohol concentration of 0.02 to 0.39, while not considered a positive result, will cause the employee to be removed from duty for eight hours or the duration of the work day, whichever is longer, and the employee will be subject to disciplinary action. An alcohol concentration of less than 0.02 will be considered a negative result. 
(d)  The city affirms the need to protect individual dignity, privacy and confidentiality throughout the testing process. If at any time the integrity of the testing procedures or the validity of the test result is compromised, the test will be cancelled. Minor inconsistencies or procedural flaws not affecting the test result will not result in a cancelled test. 
(e)  The alcohol testing form (ATF) required by 49 CFR Part 40, as amended, shall be used for all required BAC tests. An employee's failure or refusal to sign step 2 of the ATF shall be considered a refusal to submit to testing. The ATF may be found on the world wide web at the following address: http://www.dot.gov/ost/ 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 11)) 
Sec. 23-272. - Pre-employment testing. 
(a)  All applicants for employment with the city shall undergo urine testing prior to beginning to work. 
(b)  All offers of employment shall be extended conditional on the applicant passing a drug test. An applicant shall not begin work unless the applicant has taken a drug test with verified negative results. 
(c)  If an applicant fails a pre-employment drug test, the conditional offer of employment shall be rescinded. Failure of a pre-employment drug test will disqualify an applicant for employment for at least one year. The applicant must provide the city proof of having successfully completed a referral, evaluation, and treatment plan as described in 49 CFR Part 655.62 of subpart G. The cost of the assessment, evaluation, and any treatment will be the sole responsibility of the applicant. 
(d)  If a pre-employment test is cancelled, the city will require the applicant to take and pass another pre-employment test. 
(e)  In cases where an employee is on extended leave for a period of 90 days or more, regardless of the reason, the employee will be required to take a drug test under 49 CFR Part 655 and have negative test results before returning to work. 
(f)  An applicant with a dilute negative test result will be required to be retested. 
(g)  Applicants are required to report the results of drug and alcohol testing required by previous employers. Failure to do so will result in the employment offer being rescinded. If the applicant tested positive on a drug or alcohol test required by a previous employer, the applicant must provide the city proof of having successfully completed a referral, evaluation and treatment plan as described in 49 CFR Part 655.62 of subpart G. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 12)) 
Sec. 23-273. - Reasonable suspicion testing. 
(a)  All employees will be subject to a reasonable suspicion drug or alcohol test when the city or the employee's supervisor has reasonable suspicion to believe that the employee has used a prohibited drug and/or engaged in alcohol or prescription misuse. Reasonable suspicion means that there is objective evidence based upon specific, contemporaneous, articulable observations of the employee's appearance, behavior, speech, or body odor that are consistent with possible drug use and/or prescription or alcohol misuse. Reasonable suspicion must be made by one or more supervisors who are trained to detect the signs and symptoms of drug use and the misuse of prescription drugs or alcohol and who reasonably conclude that the employee may be adversely affected or impaired in his work performance due to drug use and/or the misuse of prescription drugs or alcohol. A reasonable suspicion test for alcohol may be performed immediately before, during, or immediately after the performance of a safety-sensitive function. A reasonable suspicion test for illegal drugs or misused prescription drug may be performed any time the employee is on duty. 
(b)  The city will be responsible for transporting the employee to the testing site. Supervisory personnel must avoid placing themselves and others in a situation which might endanger those present. The employee shall be placed on administrative leave pending test results. An employee who refuses to submit to an alcohol or drug test shall not be permitted to finish his shift and shall immediately be placed on administrative leave pending disciplinary action. 
(c)  A written record of the observations which caused the reasonable suspicion shall be prepared and signed by the supervisor(s) making the observation. This written record shall be submitted to management and shall be attached to the forms reporting the test results. 
(d)  Where there is no reasonable suspicion, but the employee (who is not already a participant in a drug or alcohol treatment program) admits the use of illegal drugs or the misuse of alcohol to a supervisor in his chain of command, the employee shall be referred to the SAP for an assessment and shall be placed on administrative leave. Because the employee referred him to management, any testing or positive test result would not be considered a violation of this chapter. Self-referral would not, however, exempt the employee from all testing as provided for in this chapter and from the associated consequences. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 13)) 
Sec. 23-274. - Post-accident testing. 
(a)  All employees will be required to undergo drug and alcohol testing if they are involved in an accident while driving a vehicle owned, leased, or routinely used by the city. All employees involved in an accident while operating machinery or equipment will be required to undergo drug and alcohol testing. In accidents involving more than one employee, any other employee whose performance or behavior cannot be completely discounted as a contributing factor to the accident will be required to undergo drug and alcohol testing. 
(b)  As soon as practicable following an accident (as defined in this chapter), the supervisor investigating the accident will notify the employee operating the vehicle, equipment, or machinery and all other employees whose performance or behavior could have contributed to causing the accident of the need for testing. The supervisor will make the determination using the best information available at the time of the decision. 
(c)  The investigating supervisor shall ensure that an employee required to be tested is tested as soon as possible, but in any event, no later than eight hours after the accident, for the presence of alcohol and no later than 32 hours for the presence of drugs. If an alcohol test is not performed within two hours after the accident, the supervisor will document the reason(s) for the delay. If the alcohol test is not administered within eight hours or the drug test within 32 hours, attempts to perform the test must cease and the reasons for the failure to test documented. 
(d)  Any employee involved in an accident must refrain from alcohol use for eight hours following the accident or until he undergoes a post-accident alcohol test. 
(e)  An employee who is subject to post-accident testing who fails to remain readily available for such testing, including notifying a supervisor of his location if he leaves the scene of the accident prior to submitting to the test may be deemed to have refused testing. 
(f)  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to require the delay of necessary medical care for the injured following an accident or to prohibit an employee from leaving the scene of an accident for the period necessary to obtain assistance in responding to the accident or to obtain necessary emergency medical care. 
(g)  In the event the employee involved in the accident cannot be tested under the city's auspices, the city may use the results of drug and alcohol post-accident tests administered by law enforcement officials. The officials must have independent authority for the test and be qualified to administer the test. The city shall obtain the result(s) in compliance with all applicable laws. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 14)) 
Sec. 23-275. - Random testing. 
(a)  Employees performing a function which can cause injury to person or damage to property will be subject to random, unannounced testing. The selection of employees shall be made by a scientifically valid method of randomly generating employee identifiers from the appropriate pool of employees. 
(b)  Dates for administering unannounced testing of randomly selected employees shall be spread reasonably throughout the calendar year, day of the week, and hour of the day. 
(c)  The percentage of employees randomly selected for drug/alcohol testing during the calendar year shall be not less than the percentages established by federal regulations for employees performing safety-sensitive functions which are subject to random testing under regulations of the Federal Transit Authority FTA. Currently, the random testing percentages established for the presence of drugs by the FTA are 50 percent of the eligible employees; the random testing percentages established for the presence of alcohol by the FTA is ten percent of the eligible employees. 
(d)  Each eligible employee shall have an equal chance of selection each time the selections are made. Employees will not be removed from the pool of eligible employees because they have been previously tested during the calendar year. 
(e)  Random testing for drugs may be performed at any time during the employee's workday. Random testing for alcohol may be performed immediately before, during, or immediately after the performance of work which has the potential to injure people or damage property. 
(f)  Employees selected to be tested are required to proceed immediately to the collection site. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 15)) 
Sec. 23-276. - Return-to-work testing. 
(a)  All employees who tested positive on a drug or alcohol test or who refused to be tested must submit to testing; test results must indicate negative results for drugs and/or alcohol; the employee must be evaluated by and released for duty by a SAP before the employee may return-to-work. The SAP will recommend return-to-work testing only after the employee has successfully completed the required treatment (as recommended by the SAP), is known to be drug and alcohol free, and causes no undue concern for the safety of the public and fellow employees. 
(b)  For an employee who had an initial positive drug test, a return-to-work drug test is required and a return-to-work alcohol test is allowed. For an employee who an initial positive alcohol test, a return-to-work alcohol test is required and a return-to-work drug test is allowed. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 16)) 
Sec. 23-277. - Follow-up testing. 
(a)  Employees who have returned to work after successfully completing treatment recommended by the SAP and who have had negative results from the return-to-work testing will be required to undergo frequent, unannounced drug and/or alcohol testing. The follow-up testing will be performed for a period ranging from one to five years, with a minimum of six tests performed the first year. After the first year, the duration and frequency of follow-up testing will be determined by the SAP and will reflect the SAP's assessment of the employee's situation and recovery progress. 
(b)  The purpose of follow-up testing is to deter and detect relapses. For that reason, follow-up testing is considered separately from and in addition to random, post-accident, reasonable suspicion and return-to-work testing. 
(Ord. of 2016(3), att.(art. 8, § 17)) 
Sec. 23-278. - Result of drug/alcohol test or refusal to undergo testing. 
(a)  An employee having a negative dilute result from a drug test will be retested. 
(b)  An employee having a verified positive drug test shall be removed from his position, informed of educational and rehabilitation programs available and referred to a SAP for assessment. No employee shall be allowed to return-to-work without the approval of the SAP and the DER. In addition, the following disciplinary actions will occur: 
(1)  As soon as practical, upon receiving notice of a verified positive drug test result, or a refusal to be tested, the DER will contact the employee's supervisor and inform him that the employee must cease work. 
(2)  The employee shall be referred to a SAP for assessment. The SAP will evaluate the employee to determine what assistance, if any, the employee needs to resolve problems associated with the prohibited drug use. 
(3)  Refusal to undergo a drug test shall be considered a positive test result and an act of insubordination and shall result in termination. A refusal to undergo testing includes the following situations: 
a.  When an employee consumes alcohol within eight hours following an accident without having first submitted to post-accident drug/alcohol testing; 
b.  When, prior to submitting to drug/alcohol testing, an employee leaves the scene of an accident without a legitimate explanation; 
c.  When an employee provides insufficient volume of a urine specimen or breath sample without a valid medical explanation (Note: the medical evaluation should take place no more than five days after the initial test attempt); 
d.  When the employee refuses, either orally or in writing, to undergo testing, or behaves in a manner so as to obstruct testing, or is absent when testing is to occur; 
e.  When an employee provides a urine sample which the MRO verifies as being adulterated or a substitute; 
f.  When an employee does not remain at the testing site until the testing process is completed; 
g.  When an employee fails to provide a urine specimen for any drug test required by 49 CFR Part 40, as amended, or by DOT regulations; 
h.  When an employee does not permit the observation or monitoring of a specimen collection; 
i.  When an employee fails or refuses to take a second test the DER or the collector has directed him to undergo; 
j.  When an employee fails or refuses to undergo a medical examination or evaluation, as directed by the MRO, as part of the verification process or as directed by the DER as part of the "shy bladder" or "shy lungs" procedures; 
k.  When an employee fails to cooperate with any part of the testing process, e.g., refusal to empty pockets, behaving in a confrontational manner; 
l.  When an employee fails or refuses to sign Step 2 of the alcohol testing form. 
(c)  For the first instance of a verified test result of a sample submitted for random drug/alcohol testing, where the result indicates a BAC of 0.04 or higher, actions against the employee shall include: 
(1)  Mandatory referral to SAP for assessment, formulation of a treatment plan, and signing a return-to-work agreement. Note: Failure or refusal to sign or remain in compliance with the return-to-work agreement shall result in termination of employment. Compliance with the return-to-work agreement requires the employee to submit to drug/alcohol testing prior to returning to work; negative test results; the SAP finds that the employee is cooperating with the treatment program recommended by the SAP; and the employee agrees to undergo follow-up testing. 
(2)  Refusal to undergo follow-up drug/alcohol testing shall be viewed as a direct act of insubordination, resulting in termination of employment. 
(3)  During follow-up testing, a verified positive drug or alcohol test result (BAC is 0.04 or higher) from random, reasonable suspicion, or follow-up testing will result in termination of employment. 
(d)  A verified positive post-accident or reasonable suspicion drug/alcohol test result (BAC is 0.04 or greater) shall result in termination of employment.
